PROCTEXT.PARA: Madam SPEAKER (Hon. Joan Child) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I wish to advise the House of the following ministerial arrangements: The Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown), will be absent from Australia until 20 October on Government business. During his absence the Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) will act as Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism.

—I refer the Prime Minister to the meeting between President Reagan and Mr Gorbachev at Reykjavik. I ask: Will the Prime Minister convey to both leaders the wish of the entire Australian community that, notwithstanding the lack of success at their recent meeting, the two super-powers renew their efforts to achieve an effective arms limitation agreement? Will the Prime Minister acknowledge that the outcome of the talks demonstrated the great sensitivity of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics towards the strategic defence initiative and, as a consequence, the critical importance of that initiative to the Western world? Will the Prime Minister therefore undertake to bring the policy of his Government into line with that of most other Western governments as being one of support for the strategic defence initiative, once described by his own Minister for Foreign Affairs as having a highly moral purpose? Will his Government henceforth allow Australians to participate in the wide-ranging research associated with the strategic defence initiative?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Government is naturally very disappointed that the meeting to which the Leader of the Opposition refers between President Reagan and Secretary-General Gorbachev ended without agreement, which at some points looked so likely, on key arms control and disarmament issues. As the Leader of the Opposition is aware, Australian Ministers will be briefed tomorrow by Mr Kenneth Adelman, the Director of the United States Arms Control and Disarmament Agency. Following that meeting I and my Ministers will be in a better position to make a detailed assessment not only of what has happened, but I suggest most importantly, on what are also the prospects for a resumption of the processes of dialogue which promised so much at one point but which at least temporarily have been frustrated. Our preliminary understanding is that the fundamental disagreement between the United States of America and the Soviet Union was over the relationship between the United States strategic defence initiative and reductions in offensive systems, the issue which was left unresolved at the Geneva summit. That has emerged quite clearly as the continuing main obstacle to progress. I make the point that, given the undisputed fact that very significant progress was made between the two leaders on a number of important issues, it is imperative that both the United States and the Soviet Union do not walk away now from the process of dialogue. We do indeed welcome the fact that, in statements from both sides, there are indications of continuing efforts to narrow the differences between them.

ANSWER.PARA: If I may pick up the first part of the question of the Leader of the Opposition, I can assure him that we will continue to put to both the Soviet Union and the United States the very strong view of the Australian Government, and I believe of the absolutely overwhelming majority of the Australian people-I am glad to see that the Leader of the Opposition identifies himself with us on this point-that they must continue with this process. In relation to the second part of the honourable gentleman's question, however, let me take this opportunity of endorsing the view that I have put directly to the President and that my colleague the Foreign Minister has put in his discussions in the Soviet Union, that the Australian Government does not endorse the strategic defence initiative. I have put directly to the President in quite clear language-this goes back for some time now-that we respect the integrity of the view of the United States; we simply do not identify ourselves with the initiative. We will not participate in it and we will not facilitate our participation in it.
Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, honourable members opposite can make all the noise they like, based on their apparent assumption that the Western alliance almost universally embraces SDI. If they knew anything about the facts they would know that this is simply not true. The position that we have put is understood by the President and the Administration of the United States. It has not prevented both the President and the United States Secretary of State in recent times saying that the relationship between the United States and Australia has never been in better shape.
—Ha, ha, ha!

—I notice that the Leader of the Opposition laughs. In other words, he is indicating that the President and Secretary of State Shultz are lying when they say that. They have said quite clearly and for very sound reasons that the relationship between the United States and Australia is in better shape than it has been. One of the reasons for the strength of the relationship between this Government and the United States is precisely that the United States respects the fact that while we have this close relationship it will not prevent us, when we have differences with the United States, from expressing them forcefully and clearly. They respect the fact that we have done this. The fact that the Government of Australia takes that view does not put us in some splendid isolation. That is a view shared by many countries within the Western alliance and it is a view shared by a substantial body of opinion within the United States itself. Most authoritative scientific and technical sources have launched criticism of SDI or equivalent research, and I make the point in relation to equivalent research that this Government has made it quite clear to the Government of the Soviet Union that we recognise that the Soviet Union has also been engaged in an equivalent sort of research. We have expressed to the Soviet Union the same view as we have expressed to the United States Government on this issue.

ANSWER.PARA: I conclude as I began: It seems to me that the critically important point is that all men and women of good will should recognise that substantial progress was made in the early stages, and indeed in most stages, of the recent talks. There is a substantial reason for believing that, if good will is exercised within both the United States and the Soviet Union, enough groundwork has been done upon which to erect a realistic and substantial edifice, the like of which has not been witnessed in the post-war period, of substantial reductions in nuclear armaments, and thereby substantial diminution in the threat of nuclear catastrophe which hangs over this planet.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Treasurer, relates to the annual meetings of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank from which he has just returned. I ask the Treasurer: Can he inform the House about the views of the international financial community of the Australian economy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to be able to report that there is very wide support abroad for Australia and particularly for the policies of this Government. This was apparent from not only members of the international financial community but also a range of business people interested in this country; that is, people who have invested in this country or intend to invest in this country. Of course, they are acting on the confidence that exists in Australia. I might just point out that the tone in the Australian financial markets has improved markedly in recent weeks. Today 90-day bills are trading at 16.8 per cent; they were trading at about 18 1/2 per cent in August. The rate for 10-year bonds is now 13 1/2 per cent, about one percentage point lower than in August. At noon today the trade weighted index was 52.6, which is 5 per cent higher than in August. Today's balance of payments figures show that exports are strengthening and that import volumes are falling further in the September quarter. Today's retail sales figures are good and point to significant real growth in the past three months. Employment grew in September and the labour market appeared to be stable.

ANSWER.PARA: All of this is happening because the Budget strategy is working and people know that it is working. It is working because this Government has had the courage to make the big changes necessary to adjust Australia to its diminished trading circumstances and to ensure that Australia is in a position to facilitate and accommodate structural change. At the meetings of the IMF and the World Bank and in the United States, France and Britain people expressed amazement at the level and quality of the changes which have been introduced by this Government. The fact that the Budget deficit is now forecast to be 1.4 per cent of the gross domestic product-down from 3.3 per cent, and down from the 5 per cent bequeathed to us by the former Treasurer-is a matter of great comment abroad as is the fact that our wages policy has accommodated a greater change in relative wage outcomes in this country than has been the case in any country we trade with, bar New Zealand. The quality and level of the changes is a matter of great note and comment.

The question is often put to me rhetorically, with some irony: `How come the so-called conservative parties in your country never did these things? How come the so-called people of business ran those massive Budget deficits, never freed up the exchange rate, never deregulated the financial system, never tried to change the taxation system to make it more effective, had no incomes policy and had no control over inflation?. The answer is that they do not have any policies for the future. Not only did they not have such policies in the past, but they do not have any for the future. They do not have a wages policy, a fiscal policy or any policies on taxation other than to build the tax shelters back into the system with the $5.9 billion worth of tax changes forecast by the Leader of the Opposition.

We are seeing a very clear message from people around the world that they realise that Australia has problems in its terms of trade but that it has faced the problems and put the necessary changes in place. They contrast Australia with the United States, which still has a Budget deficit of nearly 5 per cent of GDP three years after this Government came to office. They contrast the imbalance of policy in the United States, with its massive dependency on monetary policy and adjustment on the exchange rate, with the changes that have been made by Australia. They recognise the supercompetitiveness which Australia now has by way of both its exchange rate and its wages outcomes. They can see Australia trading out of its problems in the face of extreme terms of trade difficulties around the world. The message is a very buoyant one from the international markets and the international business community about the speed of the policy shifts in Australia in the face of the very difficult problems faced by the Australian economy, particularly in its terms of trade. The contrast is made with many other countries which are supposed to be flexible in policy shifts but which in fact have not shown the flexibility or the quality of the Australian changes.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Carlton The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Treasurer. The Treasurer will recall saying on 22 September, just before he went overseas:

QUESTION.PARA: There are no anomalies or defects in the design of the new fringe benefits tax and there will be no substantive changes.
I remind the Treasurer that two days later he said:
Let me make it clear about fringe benefits taxation; the Government is not going to alter the fringe benefits tax.

Given the Prime Minister's inquiry into the so-called unintended consequences of the fringe benefits tax, does the Treasurer concede that there are anomalies and defects in its design and that a substantive and wide-ranging review of the application of the fringe benefits tax is required?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Precisely as the honourable gentleman says, we are looking at the unintended consequences of the change which this legislation brings to the Australian taxation system, and it will not involve changes to the principles of the fringe benefits tax-the very principles which the lot opposite squabble over daily. Let me just indicate the clarity of the Opposition's thinking on the matter of fringe benefits! On 9 October, last Thursday, the Leader of the Opposition, when appearing on the Mike Willesee program, was asked by Willesee:

ANSWER.PARA: You're not throwing it out completely, then?
He answered:
I'm throwing their tax out completely.
I emphasise the words `their tax'. The Leader of the Opposition went on to say:
I will apply a similar approach in government-
that is, to anti-tax avoidance legislation-
and I will not tolerate arrangements that involve tax avoidance.

TALK.START.PARA: —So what?

—The `so what' is because honourable members opposite do not know what they want to do. The Opposition is opposed to tax rorts and changes but does not know what it wants to do. On the Carleton-Walsh Report, on the same day, the Leader of the Opposition said that he would not provide examples, but when pressed he made a reference to Part IVa, saying:

ANSWER.PARA: It gives you a drift.
Mr Carleton said:
A drift of your feeling?
The Leader of the Opposition answered:
A drift, yes.

The drift is that he would use Part IVa, but all that Part IVa does is give the Commissioner discretion to apply the law. Of course, the law would be applied under section 26 (e), which cannot work as it is presently drafted. So, of course, what the Leader of the Opposition is saying is, yes, he would tax avoidance procedures, making reference to Part IVa, but he does not say how he would do it. The Leader of the Opposition later said that he would legislate against such procedures. Then the Deputy Leader of the National Party said:

Mr Howard has made it clear that he is not going to allow the fringe benefit issue as such to be a great tax avoidance device. In other words, he is not going to allow company executives to have half their salary paid by kind without tax, such as providing a house, interest free loans, a Mercedes-Benz car and free education for their children. That is obviously a tax avoidance scheme.
If that is tax avoidance, where is the Opposition's basis in principle on fringe benefits and tax avoidance? Then, of course, the Leader of the National Party said:
There is already an application of some fringe benefits tax by the Tax Commissioner under 26 (e). That is the system that has continued and we have not recommended any change to that.
Further, the honourable member for O'Connor said:

We have always said we will return to the previous arrangements which existed, the arrangements whereby non-cash benefits paid in replacement of income, not giving you a car to do work in, but letting you drive it home on the weekend, a car that had no relationship to your work, or a house, your children's education-we would oblige the employee to pay tax on that. So you are basically going to be taxing it that way.
The shadow Treasurer, who asked me this question, on 2GB said that he would tackle the biggest abuses in a sensible way. He said:
I've said . . . that under the original law there was a capacity administratively . . .

So it goes on. The point is that members of the Opposition are running around like headless chooks on this issue. They say that they are opposed to rorts; that they are opposed to abuses of the tax system; but no, they will not have a fringe benefits tax and they will throw ours out. Honourable members opposite get up and ask these puny questions about whether a principle, an unintended consequence or a design feature ought to be looked at or not. I made it clear, as I said in the House in the last week I was here, that if there are administrative improvements that can be made no tax administration would be sensible if it did not make them. I stand by that. On 26 August we made an announcement in respect of employment expenses and people working overseas. The review announced by the Prime Minister last week looking at the unintended consequences of tax does not go to the principle, but the Government has a clear basis in principle in the application of its tax. Opposition members are not prepared and do not have the courage to face the difficulty and meet it with a principle. They are running around trying to hide the fact that they are opposed to fringe benefits, saying that they will junk our tax while having on their own agenda one for themselves called something else. So what about a bit of honesty and decency in the debate?

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations inform the House what steps the Government is taking to improve the involvement of employers, unions and the community in the formulation of national employment and training policies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to inform the honourable member that the Government is taking substantial steps in that direction. When we came into office there was a quite confusing array of poorly targeted, inadequately funded and unco-ordinated labour market programs, and reflecting that there was a hotchpotch of advisory and consultative bodies in the employment and training area. Over the last three and a half years we have greatly improved labour market programs. We have properly identified needs, targeted programs to meet those needs, rationalised programs and increased funding by 100 per cent. We have also been concerned to improve the consultative advisory arrangements in this area. There was a major recommendation of the Kirby Committee of Inquiry into Labour Market Programs that we provide a single, broad based mechanism for developing co-ordinated advice to government on employment and training issues.

ANSWER.PARA: Detailed consideration was given to this issue by the Government, unions and employers last year, following which I announced earlier this year that the Government would establish an Australian Council on Employment and Training as a major new advisory and promotional body in the employment and training area to advise the Government on the overall direction and development of employment and training policies; to promote public debate and discussion on these issues; to initiate research and evaluation activities; and to promote effective training throughout industry. It was also to have a broad- based membership, including both sides of industry, State and Federal governments and the wider community, and to replace and rationalise a number of existing advisory and consultative bodies.

An interim council has now provided me with a detailed strategy for implementation which has been accepted by the Government, and I can advise the House of some details regarding the formal establishment of this new Australian Council on Employment and Training. It will be established by legislation which will be introduced in the autumn sittings of next year. In the interim, it will operate on an administrative basis from 1 November. I can inform the House that an eminently well-qualified person has been selected as Chairman of the Council. He is the former Deputy Premier of South Australia and Minister for Labour, the Honourable Jack Wright, who obviously has extensive ministerial experience in the area and a particular and long-standing interest in labour market and training matters. In addition to Mr Wright, the Council will comprise three trade union representatives, three employer representatives, four State government representatives, two Federal Government representatives, up to four representatives of the wider community with interests in employment and training and a representative of the tripartite industry training committee network. These appointments will all be made in the near future and I am confident that this body will make an effective contribution to the development of employment and national training policies. In particular I look forward to ACET playing a major role in promoting improved training activities throughout the community, especially with industry, as part of the Government's drive for improved productivity and competitiveness.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Carlton The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Treasurer to his statement on 22 August when he said:

QUESTION.PARA: There are no anomalies or defects in the design of the fringe benefits tax.

I also refer the Treasurer to the attack by the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, on the Australian Taxation Office on Sunday when he said that the Tax Office was applying the fringe benefits tax to areas not intended by the Government. If, in fact, there are no anomalies or defects in the design of the legislation, how is it possible for the Tax Office to apply the fringe benefits tax in areas that were not intended? Does the Treasurer still believe that there are no anomalies or defects in the fringe benefits tax, or has the Tax Office been acting contrary to the legislation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have nothing more to add to what I said in answer to the last question. The legislation is designed to deal with the whole area of non-cash remuneration, which has been let go for years. In fact, the Commissioner of Taxation wrote to the former Treasurer about this in 1977, yet the honourable member did nothing about the matter during his tenure of office as Treasurer. It has been left to this Government to introduce legislation which will make possible the collection of taxation on non-cash benefits. As we have said in the House continually, section 26 (e) of the Income Tax Assessment Act is not able to do the job-a point disputed by the Opposition but made clear today in a speech by the Tax Commissioner himself. He said that section 26 (e) cannot and will not work and that the issue must be addressed through a fringe benefits tax.

ANSWER.PARA: It is very interesting to note that the Opposition always attacks the Government when it tries to deal with tax minimisation or avoidance. This has happened continually. The former Treasurer is now running around talking about Part IVa, saying that this is the most effective anti-avoidance legislation that has been introduced. For the benefit of the House, I spent some time yesterday going over the former Treasurer's tax record, particularly in relation to Part IVa. I remind the House of some of the details and why there could be no confidence by the Australian public in the belief that the present Opposition as a government would do any more about tax avoidance than it ever did or was driven to do. In January 1978, a month or so after the honourable member for Bennelong took office as Treasurer, he wrote to the then Leader of the House, the right honourable member for New England, foreshadowing a legislative proposal to counter pre-tax profit stripping by companies. It took the Tax Commissioner 28 memorandums covering three years finally to drive the honourable member to introduce legislation.

Let me quote some of those memorandums. On 24 May 1978 the Commissioner said that there were 30 cases of straw company evasion reported from Adelaide to which the then Treasurer had been alerted on that date. The Commissioner pointed out that there was an even more serious situation in Melbourne. The same memorandum outlined the quite significant losses to revenue resulting from such schemes. A further memorandum from the Commissioner on 20 July 1978 indicated that taxation avoidance involving straw companies was `very widespread indeed' and pointed to the pressing need for submission 2290 to be dealt with by Ministers and for the examination recommended to be carried out. Finally, on 23 August 1978 Ministers agreed that officers from the Taxation Office and the Attorney-General's Department would examine as a matter of urgency the problem of tax evasion through straw companies and trusts and prepare, if appropriate, a submission on the question of introducing into the law an appropriate criminal offence.

On 17 November 1978 Commissioner O'Reilly sent a further memorandum to the former Treasurer saying that he had word that the Treasurer had expressed misgivings over some of the reverse onus of proof provisions. He went on to say:

Without that kind of onus on the defendant, it would be open to serious doubt whether a prosecution could ever succeed. Clearly the potential revenue losses that these schemes make possible require an effective deterrent and the provision must be made capable of that.

Then for months he wrote asking the former Treasurer to write to the Attorney-General in order to get opinions, and finally on 25 July 1979-1 1/2 years after he began the correspondence-the Commissioner sent another memo- randum saying:
It is my considered advice that the situation needs to be remedied urgently and with stern measures.
He also referred to the serious and growing problems of straw companies and straw trust evasion. Then, on 7 November 1979, the Commissioner was forced to write to the then Treasurer, again saying:
I am gravely concerned that there may be some question about going ahead with the planned legislation on this matter.

He got the message back from the apparatus that they did not want to press on, that they did not want to do anything about it. Then, on 8 November, the honourable member for Bennelong wrote to the Commissioner and attempted to persuade the Commissioner of Taxation that it was desired to defer the legislation. The former Treasurer wrote to the Commissioner trying to talk him out of it. The Commissioner wrote back saying:
I think there is a lot to be said in favour of introducing the legislation at this time.

He received further advice from the Commissioner on 15 November, again referring to his `grave concern with the straw company situation' and saying `it is a feasible course for the legislation to be introduced' at that time and it should be allowed to lie on the table `until the autumn sittings'. Then, on 15 February 1980, the Commissioner again wrote to the former Treasurer noting:
. . . trust stripping activities have been and are being conducted on a wide scale.

On 10 June 1980 the Commissioner wrote and said that the alternative-the alternative of the committee which the former Treasurer had pushed him to; some tax advisory committee-`does not offer a solution to the problem'. He said further:
. . . it is becoming increasingly important that something be done to halt straw company and straw trust evasion.

He then wrote on 22 October 1980 and referred to the situation as `critical', referring to the critical need for legislation in the area of straw companies and trusts. Then he wrote on 31 October 1980 and said this:
I must draw your attention to the gravity of the situation.
This is the language of a bureaucrat. He added:
. . . company tax evasion following sales of shares in companies is being practised on an alarming scale, and quite openly.

That is the language of the Commissioner to the former Treasurer on 31 October 1980, two years after the former Treasurer became Treasurer. Then the former Treasurer introduced the Bill on 5 November 1980. This is what Mr Waterford, who followed the issue in the Canberra Times, had to say:
Far from the picture presented at the Tax Office which did not tell him enough of what was going on in 1978 and 1979, the record shows a continual flow of information from Mr O'Reilly to Mr Howard.
He went on further to say:

. . . it shows Mr O'Reilly waging a lonely war throughout a bureaucratic, political and business thicket to keep the item high on the agenda, fighting off cold feet from almost everyone involved and occasionally using very heavy artillery indeed.
He went on to say, referring to the former Treasurer:
. . . he needed considerable prodding from Mr O'Reilly to keep the matter high on the agenda, that drastic criminal legislation was necessary.

That was the form of the honourable member for Bennelong. In this debate he is on record on the Carleton-Walsh Report and Willesee as saying: `My Part IV legislation was the toughest anti-avoidance legislation ever'. He said: `Therefore, my credentials on fringe benefits will be okay, as they were okay on straw companies and strips'. There is his record on straw companies and strips: Three years and 28 pleading memos from the Commissioner of Taxation, not to do something about the rutted in fringe benefits, but to do something about the abusive, criminal, open, overt paper avoidance schemes-the most obvious things that any government with any shred of tax decency or morality would have moved straight into and closed. I say to the former Treasurer that there are no such memos in my administration or in the administration of this Government. The working class boy was quite prepared to represent the slick end of the Liberal Party's interests, the slick money out there, the people working the paper avoidance schemes, the real ramps and rorts. Not only was the former Government not prepared to touch fringe benefits, which is a massive area of evasion of the income tax scheme; it would not touch even the criminal paper avoidance schemes.

When the McCabe-Lafranchi report came in the Leader of the Opposition labelled it a political stunt by Premier Cain. When the Costigan report came in his defence was that, because of the secrecy provisions of section 16, he did not know the names of the taxpayers so he could not do anything about it. But he had 28 memos-some of them ran to 10 and 12 pages-pleading with him to do something about the paper schemes. Part IVa came from the outraged public debate; it never came from John Howard, any more than any other decent tax legislation came or ever would come from the coalition parties.

So honourable members opposite should not get up and attack us about dealing with the tax system and the avoidance of the income tax system by attempting to deal with non-cash benefits under the fringe benefits tax. If there are unintended consequences the Government will deal with them, but it will stand by the principle of fairness and decency in the tax system, something which is alien to those opposite. They should not get up and talk to us about their record on Part IVa because they were driven and dragged screaming to do something about tax avoidance on a scale unparalleled in the Western world, in the United States of America, in Europe and in Britain-in fact, a blot upon Australian society at a time when criminal activities were let go despite pleadings by a Commissioner of Taxation. That is the record of the coalition and the record that coalition statements ought to be judged against.

TALK.START.PARA: —Wind up.

—I know the right honourable gentleman wants me to wind up. He would have been sitting there protecting the tax avoiders, too. That is the record of members of the coalition. They are the standards by which they should be judged, and that is why we reject absolutely any moral standard on their part when assessing the legislation of the Government.

—Has the attention of the Minister for Foreign Affairs been drawn to an editorial in the Canberra Times of 9 October last calling on the Australian Government urgently to pursue allegations by the Simon Wiesenthal Centre about the presence in Australia of nazi war criminals? Can the Minister inform honourable members what action has been taken to follow up these allegations since they were handed to the Government? Can he assure the House that the Government will ensure that anybody living in Australia who is guilty of war crimes shall not be able to escape the consequences?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to commence by acknowledging the positive contribution which the honourable member made in the setting up of the Menzies inquiry into allegations concerning alleged war criminals in Australia. It was a substantial and important one widely acknowledged by those many people who are concerned to see this matter properly pursued. On 1 October this year in New York at the Australian permanent mission to the United Nations I met Rabbis Hier and Cooper of the Simon Wiesenthal Centre based in Los Angeles. They provided me with a list of 40 names of alleged war criminals from the Baltic States area who it was alleged had migrated to Australia in the fairly near post-war period. I was further advised that there would be another 140 to 160 names provided when additional information was compiled concerning those people. I can assure the honourable member that the Government is doing everything it can to pursue these matters. However, we must bear in mind that there are requirements on us to proceed according to the principles of our legal system and to ensure that the substance of evidence is established to uphold any allegations and that due processes are respected and properly pursued. All this will be done. I say that because, first, I want to register that there are obligations on us, having accepted the submission from the Simon Wiesenthal Centre, to ensure that the evidence is there, and because secondly, I want to stress that I have concluded that this exercise will take perhaps some considerable time.

ANSWER.PARA: If I illustrate at this point with some quotes, without divulging the names of the people involved, from the documents that were supplied to me, I think honourable members will readily recognise that there is a substantial task ahead for the Menzies inquiry to establish the nature of evidence behind these allegations. I will give three cases, but not the names. They show the nature of the information given to us: The name, date of birth and the allegation. One at which I am looking states that the person participated in murders of Jews in a particular place. The source was Yad Vashem archives. Then there is some very brief information of no more than about 20 words about immigration data. Another case shows the name supplied and date and place of birth of a police officer in a particular place who was involved in the murder of Jews and the robbery of valuables. It gives some details of his police rank and place and some brief immigration data. The third case again gives the date of birth and states that the person was the leader of a local special murder squad in a particular place and carried out annihilation of the Jewish community, and it gives some details of a very high ranking position. The sources-numerous lists of Latvian war criminals, Yad Vashem and so on-and brief immigration data are given.
Only a little over 20 addresses in Australia in respect of these 40 names have been provided, and this caveat has been supplied:

Here is a list of names, some of which contain first names as well as last names of the suspected criminals. Others on the list contain a similar first name initial and same last name. While we cannot--
it is stressed--

absolutely vouch for the accuracy of these addresses or telephone numbers, or that these are actually the same individuals listed on our suspected war criminals list, it can, however, be used as a preliminary basis for your further investigation.

I quote that evidence to indicate that a substantial amount of work is still to be done. Basic information has been provided and allegations have been put forward but, for a case to be established in each case, if it is recommended by the Menzies inquiry which is under the administration of the Special Minister of State, there will have to be substantial further investigation. The Government will do all that it properly should do, and it will do it resolutely; it will do it properly according to the principles of justice which apply in this country.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Conquest Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Treasurer to his statement of 8 August, when asked about possible changes to the fringe benefits tax, in which he said:

QUESTION.PARA: It's a total furphy, a total furphy. The Government is not going to change this tax.
I also refer the Treasurer to his statement of 12 August when he said:
There's not going to be any administrative changes-that's it.

Why was it that the Prime Minister discovered the unintended consequences of the fringe benefits tax only while the Treasurer was overseas? Does the Treasurer still hold the view that he expressed last Friday in London that the review of the fringe benefits tax is a sideshow? If so, will the Treasurer and the Prime Minister be taking this sideshow on the road to Queensland during the State election?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —What I said in London was that a review of the unintended consequences of the fringe benefits tax was a sideshow to the main event, the health of the Australian economy-and it is. Whoever drafted this question for the honourable member for Hinkler will soon learn that what I said about the main event is right, and the main event is the Australian economy. Here we have a government that is totally restructuring the Australian economy and bringing it back to health, trying to rebuild quickly our import competing structure-our fight-back machinery which was decimated by the former Government and so is not there to be used now in the face of a terms of trade collapse. We have made the major structural changes to permit the Australian economy to grow again. As the indicators that I read out earlier change, honourable members opposite will eat their political hearts out. They will eat their political hearts out as we move towards the next election and we see these changes falling into place for the Government like apples in a slot machine. I say to Opposition members that I reject out of hand their puny, weak questions for what they are-irrelevant to the main business at hand, which is to make sure that the tax changes are good, sensible and useful and do their job but at the same time seeing the true economic security of Australians built week by week as the changes the Government has brought into place wreak their effect upon the real Australian economy. As that happens and as domestic and international confidence grows the political position of members of the Opposition will weaken. They will need more than a question drafted by the staff of the Leader of the Opposition to save their position at the next poll.

I have nothing to add to what I said in answer to earlier questions. It will take more than the man for his times who is sitting opposite-the times when the terms of trade were collapsing on us, the price of all our commodities was down, the balance of payments was eroding and the Government was beavering away to get the Budget changes into place-to save the mob opposite.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The defence policy of this Government is to pursue a disciplined relationship between strategy and force structure within the constraints of what is financially feasible in a period of economic stringency. Within this framework virtually every aspect of the defence of this country is being analysed and modernised to meet Australia's real defence needs in the 1980s. The annual statement of the Defence Minister necessarily focuses on outlays. It is more appropriate to argue elsewhere aspects of broad strategy. Nevertheless, because we have closely linked the three essential elements of defence policy, it is necessary briefly to state strategy and what has been achieved in matching it to budgetary possibilities.

SPEECH.PARA: It is sometimes argued that what is needed is a statement of the desirable in the structure of the Australian defence forces and damn the dollar. This makes great copy but disastrous policy. Such an unstructured approach left us with armed forces undercapitalised when this Government took office-an undercapitalisation which was in no small measure due to an inability to take decisions to cut unnecessary capabilities and to reduce inefficiency elsewhere in the program. This left us with some serious gaps in our force structure, as amply described by Paul Dibb.

Our strategy is for defence self-reliance. It is self-reliance against a background that recognises that we have regional responsibilities that must be addressed after we have assigned first priority to our own needs. It is self-reliance also within the framework of a wider alliance with the United States. Our alliance and agreements with the United States, in particular, but also with New Zealand and other South Pacific and South East Asian states, impacts on strategy, force structure and Budget outlays largely in positive ways. We receive at reasonable cost essential capabilities in the intelligence, scientific and equipment areas which reduce the number of expensive tasks we would otherwise have to perform.

The relationships also help to create a strategic environment which is relatively benign. Unlike many countries, we can say with confidence that it would take years for a potential enemy to develop the military capability to mount an attack on us of sufficient magnitude to destroy our society. We also realise, however-this is an important point-that capabilities for lower level threats both to our national interests and those of our friends and neighbours do exist within the region. In this case the emergence of such threats is a product not of capability but of politics. A political situation can change rapidly and this Government accepts that there is a requirement for it to be able to counter such challenges should they emerge. Of course, the warning time of such challenges can be short.

It is a pity that the disciplined approach of this Government has been the object of Opposition sniping based on a combination of deliberate misunderstanding of key elements of Government strategy including warning time doctrine and the intellectual sloppiness of unrealistic forward defence strategies that the Opposition itself abandoned in government in the 1970s. These ill-informed and unco-ordinated criticisms have been accompanied by an absolute determination that no more will be spent on defence than we are spending. As the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair) said only last month: `We have got to reduce taxes and frankly I think that has a higher priority for me as far as the Budget is concerned before you decide what you are going to spend on defence'. Therefore, in the unlikely event of a resumption of office by the Opposition, we can expect the gaps in defence which we are closing to be replaced by other areas of deficiency.

This Government is tackling all of the problems that the Opposition generated or ignored. Our equipment is being updated, our command arrangements streamlined and strengthened and our factories rationalised. Most importantly, we have addressed key aspects of the conditions of service of service personnel. We have done so on the basis that, whilst all in the community must share some of the burdens imposed by our economic circumstances, unusual burdens should not be borne by the forces. Like all Australians, they are entitled to an independent review of their conditions and they have that now under our independent tribunal. The Services are entitled to decent housing. They will get that, after years of Opposition meandering, through our increased financial commitment of some $66m in this Budget, as the start of a major program, and through an independent statutory authority. The problems of service personnel are complex, as Sue Hamilton established in her report. Moneys are being made available in this Budget to implement her suggestions for improving the conditions of service spouses and families.

Project management and the defence factories are being reformed so that they can contribute to the exciting industrial opportunities offered by the major re-equipment of the Defence Force now under way. The roles and functions of the joint facilities are being explained to Australians with a new honesty and a new respect for the interest taken by Australians in global strategic issues. The resources to realise all these commitments are coming from real growth in the defence budget, and from major reforms in administration.

This Government's undertaking to increase defence spending in real terms has been met over four consecutive Labor Budgets with an average annual real growth of 2.7 per cent. The Government's commitment to real growth in defence spending has been amply demonstrated this year. Under the toughest budgetary discipline faced by any government for many years, defence spending has been budgeted to grow by one per cent in real terms. In a year when Government outlays overall have not been allowed to grow at all, this is a remarkable outcome. It is even more remarkable in the light of the severe effect on the defence budget of the dollar's depreciation. The defence budget has been insulated from the effect of the low dollar, which has been taken into account before calculating real growth in the defence budget.

Under this Government, defence spending has reached record peacetime levels. This year's defence budget is $7,415m, an increase of $743m or 11.1 per cent in actual terms over last year's outlays. Defence spending this year constitutes 9.9 per cent of Commonwealth Budget outlays and 2.9 per cent of gross domestic product-sustaining the highest GDP share of defence spending since the days of the Vietnam war in the early 1970s. Within the defence budget, reforms are being made which will save over $30m in a full year. Rationalisation of the defence factories has resulted in significant staff reductions. Management is being improved and new work practices are being negotiated.

More than 80 per cent of this budget is allocated directly to the Defence Force for new equipment and facilities, personnel and operations. Three per cent is allocated directly in support of defence industry and production activities, 2 per cent for defence research and development, one per cent for defence co-operation and one per cent for expenditure by other departments. Service pensions account for another 5 per cent and 5 per cent is for the Department of Defence policy elements and central, regional and overseas administration in support of defence programs.

The key focus in this year's defence budget is long term investment in equipment and facilities, to continue the re-equipping of the ADF with up to date capabilities tailored to our strategic needs. One-third-33.2 per cent- of this year's defence budget will be spent on new equipment and facilities, easily the highest for more than 15 years and double the rate of 17 per cent achieved by the coalition in 1981-82. In all, over 130 major equipment projects are under way this year, and decisions will be made this year on many more. The most important of these will be the new submarine project. Within a few weeks we will be receiving tenders from the two submarine consortiums, and a decision will be made in the middle of next year on which company will design and construct our new submarines. Among the major equipment purchases being made this year are Seahawk and Blackhawk helicopters, PC9 trainers for the Royal Australian Air Force, Steyr rifles for the Army, a wide range of trucks for the Army, Harpoon and standard missiles for the Royal Australian Navy and short and medium range missiles for the Air Force and air defence weapons for the Army.

The total of nearly $2.2 billion being spent on re-equipping the ADF this year is directed to reshaping the Defence Force to meet the specific strategic needs and challenges of our environment. Priority is being given to high technology solutions to the problems posed by the unique terrain over which the ADF could be called upon to operate. Among the most challenging tasks for the ADF is surveillance of the vast areas to our north. I am therefore delighted to announce the Government's decision to proceed with a major project to develop a comprehensive over the horizon radar system to cover the whole of our northern approaches. Based on the technology developed by Australian defence scientists and engineers of the Electronics Research Laboratory in South Australia through the Jindalee project, this system will provide comprehensive coverage of air and shipping movements throughout the air-sea gap to our north far more cheaply than any other system.

It is planned that at least two, and probably three, new OTHR sites will be established, one or two in north-eastern Australia and one in the west or south-west. At the same time further development is being carried out at the existing OTHR site near Alice Springs to refine the equipment and operating procedures. Total cost of this project, including a network of three stations, will amount to approximately $500m. Jindalee is just one example of the Government's intention to develop a force structure for the ADF which directly guards the weaknesses and exploits the strengths of Australia's strategic environment.

Another important project under way this year is the conversion of the RAAF's existing fleet of four 707 aircraft for air to air refuelling of the FA18s. We must look continually for useful force multipliers for air operations. Increasing familiarity with problems of interception in and from the north is demonstrating the need for range in our primary air assets and the need for more time on task. So this will greatly enhance the ADF's capabilities to project power throughout Australia's area of military interest.

We have commenced preliminary work on the Navy's next generation of warships, the new surface combatant. Under this project I intend to seek Government approval to build, in Australia, up to eight ships to meet the requirements identified by the Navy and by Dibb for a large number of light, capable vessels to operate throughout Australia's surrounding maritime areas. The importance of this project should not be underestimated. It is comparable in size-indeed greater-to the submarine project. It will have higher Australian content. It will have greater export potential. It will proceed alongside the submarine project, having a shorter start-up period. We regard it as providing the Navy with more decks to perform essential wartime tasks in focal points and in support of the heavier warships. In peacetime it will give us additional useful capabilities to demonstrate Australian concern for the surveillance needs of our neighbours.

It is hoped that requests for proposals for this project will be issued later this year, and that construction of the vessels will commence in the early 1990s. The project is currently estimated at $3.5 billion. Expenditure this year on major facilities projects includes $70m on the development of the air base at Tindal in the Northern Territory and $23m on the construction of an air base at Derby in Western Australia, and we have decided to provide facilities for the new Blackhawk helicopters at Townsville at an estimated cost of $19m. These and other projects reflect the Government's commitment to defending the north of Australia by providing appropriate facilities for ADF deployments there. In excess of $500m will be spent this year on developing and maintaining defence facilities and housing around the country.

The Government is seeking to achieve substantial economies in the management of defence assets and operations through management reorganisation, the rationalisation of defence production establishments and initiatives aimed at accelerating the disposal of surplus defence equipment, land holdings, plant and machinery. The thrust of these improvements has been to delegate responsibility and authority, reduce complexity and duplication and simplify lines of control. Creation of the Office of Capital Procurement was the first major step in this regard. It brings together the functional areas responsible for the procurement of approved major capital equipment, including financial programming and budgeting, with the areas responsible for procurement policy and procedures, defence industry policy and participation by Australian industry in the supply of equipment. Clear lines of authority are now provided for major equipment acquisition through every stage of a project. The Office of Defence Production within my Department now administers fifteen defence factories employing over 13,000 people.

The management improvement programs initiated by this Government have had to be complemented by rationalisation of the operations of Williamstown and Garden Island dockyards and the Government Aircraft Factories. Staff reductions have been made not only at the factory level but also in the central office in Canberra, where a reduction of over 12 per cent has already been achieved. The Government has also decided to close the Albion Explosives Factory in Melbourne and dispose of the aircraft engineering workshop at Pooraka, near Adelaide. The capabilities of the Albion factory will be transferred to the Mulwala Explosives Factory. The Albion site will be cleared and will eventually be returned to general community use.

I have also announced the Government's decision to establish the Government Aircraft Factories as a government owned company. This decision recognises that the Government Aircraft Factories is an important competitor in the Australian aerospace industry and one that is destined to become a more important commercial force. In these circumstances it makes sense to ensure that the Government Aircraft Factories is placed on the same commercial footing as its private sector competitors.

As part of the process of rationalising our defence industry, the sale and release to Australian industry of Commonwealth owned machinery was begun with a major review in April this year. Nearly 20,000 items are issued on loan or lease to hundreds of Australian companies and those immediately available for disposal are expected to realise at least $14m this financial year with further returns in coming years. Australian industry will directly reap the benefits of nearly $1,800m in the defence budget. The sum of $380m will be spent on major capital equipment projects, including $82m for the basic trainer, $76m for the Australian-built frigates and $64m on a range of communications and electronics equipment, particularly radios-projects Parakeet and Raven-and fixed communications-DISCON. In addition, industry will be substantially involved in projects such as assembly of the Seahawk and Blackhawk helicopters and continued work on the FA18 aircraft, with the advantages that these activities bring to industry through the transfer of advanced technology, skills and capabilities. A further $900m will be spent here in the manufacturing and service industries for other equipment, stores and repair.

I have today released details of measures the Government has approved to assist Australian industry to bid for defence work and to develop and export military and related products. The list of measures is based on preliminary recommendations from my ministerial consultant, Bob Cooksey, from industry itself and from within the Department. Austrade is to become directly involved in selling defence products, the flow of information to industry will be improved, defence expertise, equipment and manpower will be made more readily available and export controls will be reviewed. In future defence projects, it is our intention to keep Commonwealth ownership of assets to an absolute minimum. This will mean simpler dealings with industry and less bureaucracy.

The Government regards the improvement of service conditions, particularly for members of the ADF, as among the most pressing defence priorities. The Hamilton report on supporting service families has provided a valuable basis for alleviating some of the harsher aspects of service life. A team has now been established to implement measures to deal with these problems. Defence housing has been overhauled, with an independent authority being established to administer the 22,000 homes for which Defence is responsible. Spending on housing will rise by 20 per cent to $66m.

As part of the major overhaul of conditions of service in the ADF, the Government has established a Defence Force Remuneration Tribunal. For the first time the pay of service men and women is now set by an independent tribunal, in line with normal Australian practice, instead of by the government of the day. The Tribunal has already made a general determination on Services pay, which produced a rise of 5.9 per cent, and is now to consider certain allowances.

The approved strength of the regular Defence Force will remain unchanged at 70,529, although actual numbers were below this level at 30 June 1986. The planned terminal strengths for 1986-87 are 15,732 for the Navy, 32,000 for the Army and 22,797 for the Air Force. The Army Reserve numbers are planned to increase during 1986-87 to 24,500, up from 23,145 at the end of 1985-86.

Resignation rates among officers have been unusually high in recent months. This is partly due to structural factors, such as the passage through the ADF's career structure of a hump originating in the high recruitment levels during the Vietnam War. High resignation rates also reflect strong job prospects outside the ADF, especially for some classes of highly trained officers such as pilots. The requirement to match salary to rank makes it impossible for the ADF to match the offers that highly trained young officers can attract from private employers in some categories. But neither the Government nor the ADF is content to assume that such factors tell the whole story on high resignation rates, and the CDF is undertaking a study to ascertain any other factors which may be taken into account in trying to address this problem.

In line with the Government decision on rationalisation of the work force at defence factories and dockyards, civilian personnel numbers overall will decline in 1986-87, in staff years, by some 850. The reduction also includes the rundown in locally engaged civilians at Butterworth, Malaysia. Average civilian staffing numbers planned for 1986-87 are 39,713.

The command structure of the ADF is being modernised and strengthened to meet the demands of a self-reliant defence posture. Increasingly the three Services of the ADF are being designed to fight together as one independent force, and this requires that planning and administration of the services is increasingly centralised in HQADF. A major step was taken in this direction in June with the creation of the position of Vice Chief of the Defence Force to co-ordinate the force development planning activities of the three Services.

The role of the Reserves is also being re- assessed as part of the Government's program to optimise the ADF to meet the requirements of our strategic circumstances. The Government regards the Reserves as an integral part of the ADF, and plans to enhance the functions and responsibilities of reserve units to reflect this. Options are being examined to allocate the Reserves more weapons and roles. For the Army Reserve, consideration is being given to equipping it with heavier weapons, including tanks and medium artillery, and to allocating particular wartime functions to specific reserve units. Consideration is being given to increasing the use of the Navy Reserve in the mine counter-measures area, and maintenance and airfield defence roles to the Air Force Reserve. Each of these functions would be vital in even low level hostilities, and the Government is legislating to allow limited call-out of the Reserves in situations short of a declared defence emergency. Incentives will be introduced to improve recruitment and retention for the Reserve Forces in recognition of their enhanced role. The Government will restore full taxation exemption of the pay of Defence Force reservists from 1 January 1987. At the same time the special Reserve allowance will be discontinued as an offset. In addition, the Government will increase Army Reserve training days from the Budget level of 900,000 last year to 942,000 this year. All these initiatives will enhance the development of a defence force with capabilities relevant to self-reliant defence of Australia. But we do not do this in isolation. This Government recognises the importance to our security of effective relations with our regional neighbours and with our traditional friends. It is to these relationships that I now turn.

The Government is devoting increased resources to co-operative defence activities within the Pacific Island countries and Papua New Guinea. An amount of $34.8m has been allocated to such activities in this year's Budget, compared with expenditure of $27.1m in 1985-86. Much of the increase reflects the gathering pace of the Pacific patrol boat project, which has been developed to assist the South Pacific Forum countries to upgrade their maritime surveillance capabilities to maintain sovereignty over their extensive exclusive economic zones. Countries now participating in the project include Papua New Guinea and Fiji, each of which is to receive four boats; and the Solomon Islands, Vanuatu, Western Samoa and the Cook Islands, which will each receive one boat.

Construction of the vessels is now well advanced at Australian Shipbuilding Industries (WA) Pty Ltd yard in Western Australia. Crews are being trained in Australia and the participating countries are developing, with advice from RAN experts in-country, the necessary infra- structure and management systems to receive the boats in service. The first boat will be completed in February 1987. This project demonstrates the Government's firm commitment to co-operate in practical ways with the South Pacific Forum countries to enhance the security of our common region. We would hope that they will continue to view Australia as a primary partner in defence matters.

The Government has also made provision for continuing defence co-operation with our neighbours in the Association of South East Asian Nations, where funds allocated in 1986-87 total some $19.5m. With the increasing sophistication of these countries in defence matters, co-operative activities are now focused on sharing training experience and the transfer of Australian defence expertise through professional exchanges and consultancies.

The changes which have occurred in the United States of America-New Zealand relationship as a result of the dispute over ship visits have not affected the fundamental United States-Australia relationship under the ANZUS alliance. When the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) and I met with Secretary Shultz and Secretary Weinberger in San Francisco earlier this year, we reaffirmed that the ANZUS Treaty remained in place and that the relationship between Australia and the United States under the Treaty, and the rights and obligations assumed by Australia and the United States towards each other under ANZUS, would remain constant and undiminished. The same, of course, applies to our wider co-operative defence relationship with the United States, which is facilitated by the ANZUS alliance and which includes such mutually beneficial activities as combined exercises, co-operation in research and development, and personnel and intelligence exchanges. These activities assist Australia to develop and maintain its self-reliant defence capability.

This Government views our alliance with the United States as a dynamic relationship, which is being developed and strengthened to meet the evolving needs of both parties. One exciting new development is the agreement between ourselves and the United States Navy jointly to develop an Australian invention-Project Nulka. This will involve our co-operation in the development of a defensive system for surface ships. The United States has withdrawn its security commitment to New Zealand until the port access issue is resolved. New Zealand is well aware of Australia's own views and policies on port access. The issue has not, however, affected Australia's bilateral defence relationship and activities with New Zealand, which derive from long-standing, overlapping national defence and strategic interests.

In this statement I have highlighted the main features of the defence budget and indicated this Government's resolve to build a defence force relevant to Australia's self-reliant defence. The Government will shortly bring down a White Paper on defence which will provide a clear and practical blueprint for the continuing development of the defence of this nation. This Government has brought to the defence of Australia a new rationale, a new honesty with the Australian people and new hardware for the armed forces. The Opposition offers old fears, outworn slogans and old equipment. This Government has an absolute commitment to renew Australia's defences from top to bottom and an absolute commitment to provide the defence spending to do it. The Opposition is tied to the past by its 1950s strategic cliches and its absolute commitment to cut defence spending.

I conclude on a note with regard to the Secretary to my Department. I would like to take this opportunity to record my appreciation and that of the Government for the services of the Secretary to my Department, Sir William Cole, who will retire tomorrow. Sir William has an outstanding record of achievement in his Public Service career; a career which spans some 40 years, the last three of which have been as Secretary to the Department of Defence. He has made a very significant contribution to the development of these new directions in Australian defence policy and I thank him for that. As a further aid to responsible and reasoned debate on defence, I table the 1985-86 Defence Report. I also present the following paper:

TALKER.NAME: Mr SINCLAIR
