TALK.START.PARA: —I begin by rebutting the conclusion in the penultimate paragraph of the statement of the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley), that is, the Opposition's absolute commitment to cut defence spending, for the reverse is the truth. We believe it absolutely essential not only that there be a maintenance of a reasonable percentage of the Budget for defence but also that there be an equally absolute requirement that at this time funds for defence within the Budget be not only maintained but increased to meet this nation's requirements for defence. From our point of view it is essential that an adequate percentage of this country's overall Budget be provided for defence. While we are most concerned at the deficit and at the way in which the Government is increasing taxes and abusing its economic responsibilities, we believe that defence must have a priority and are very concerned at the direction this country is taking.

SPEECH.PARA: There is much to be commended in the Minister's statement, but equally there is much to be condemned. In my analysis of the Minister's statement, I wish, first of all, to look at the strategic situation and then to pick up some of the details of the spending. However, as far as the Minister's concluding remarks about Sir William Cole are concerned, I would like to share in wishing Sir William Cole a long, happy and healthy retirement. I express surprise that only once since he has been administering the Department of Defence have I had an opportunity to talk to him. It seems to be one of the extraordinary parts of this administration that it is so difficult to get information from people within the Department. It is also somewhat of a disappointment that, on the eve of his retirement, there has still been no announcement by the Government as to who is to be his successor.

There is much that needs to be said on the strategic basis on which Mr Dibb has enunciated his program for the Government and on which the Government has produced a White Paper, but it can wait until the White Paper itself is produced. It is of interest that today the Minister, in his statement, has picked up some of our concerns on this side of the House as to the interpretation of self-reliance and as to the role of the Australian defence forces. We see the responsibility of the Australian Defence Force as, of course, defending Australia, but we then look at Australia having a wider responsibility than just its territorial limits. The fortress Australian extension of doctrine that we read into the Dibb analysis is something we believe inadequate for the strategic situation that Australia faces in the South Pacific, South East Asia and indeed the wider world in 1986.

We are concerned that Australia's national interests, Australia's Territories and those areas where Australia's foreign policy can be assisted by a strong defence policy can be helped by an Australian Defence Force able to play a positive role. It is our concern that in the new force structure which the Minister envisages there seems to be a lesser ability than we believe desirable for our defence forces to play the sort of role that we see necessary, particularly in our region. While I am delighted that the Minister has picked up the fact that self-reliance must be seen against a background which recognises that we have regional responsibilities, we say to the Minister that any definition of denial that does not include complete co-ordination of our defence stratagem with countries in our region, we would believe inadequate. It is in that regard in particular that we are concerned about the overall strategic base from which he looks at Australia's defence policy.

I think this is all particularly pertinent because it comes immediately following the Reykjavik discussions between the leaders of the two super-powers of the world. There is no doubt that President Reagan and Secretary Gorbachev in their discussions were looking at matters that have a very profound influence on Australia. I refer to that wider strategic base because on this side of the House we are concerned that in the International Year of Peace too many people seem to fail to comprehend the fact that the Australian Defence Force is in the front line of the peace corps of this nation. If one has a strong defence, if one is able to deter aggression, it is unlikely that one would have to use the forces of this country actually to fight.

On this side of the House our objective is to make sure that we have a deterrent, non-nuclear capability within our Defence Force so that, if there were to be any developing threat against Australia, those who would see Australia as being a prospective target would know that in turn they could expect to be hit and hurt if they should ever think of launching an attack upon us. It is because of that concern that we worry about the general defence relationship in our defence alliances. While the Minister in his statement has referred in passing to the relationship in ANZUS and the relationship with New Zealand, we do not believe that the Government has been anywhere near strong enough in taking up with the New Zealanders the concern that we have that it is not possible for Australia to maintain a constant level of support for New Zealand in the way that we did when it was a member of the ANZUS relationship. We believe that New Zealand must be persuaded to take a course in which it accepts once again its responsibilities in this region so that collectively we can again mount that common barrier against aggression which existed since World War II or shortly thereafter.

Indeed, I think it is particularly important, when we think of deterrence and our relationship with the United States and within ANZUS and the Minister's comments that he believes they are as strong, that we consider the almost apologetic response given by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in his answer to a question today in talking about the relations between this Government and the United States. As far as we are concerned, I think it is important that we make sure that there is a constant and continuing comprehension by the United States that we do not see the written terms of ANZUS as the only basis of our defence relationship but that we see it also as something that extends beyond that; that as much of what is unwritten as is written is important in ensuring that Australia can play its part in the wider world scene to preserve peace.

We are concerned that the Government seems to have taken such an intransigent attitude towards the strategic defence initiative. Once again, the Prime Minister today has declared his opposition to this doctrine. He seems to ignore almost the degree to which the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics is already involved in that field, although I was interested that for the first time we have had a report from the Prime Minister suggesting that he has actually taken up with the Soviet Union his concern about its progress in that field. The reality is that the strategic defence initiative is just that; it is a defence initiative that is designed to ensure that if there should be a missile attack on a country there is a capability of defending the people of that country against that missile attack.

I believe that it is very foolish indeed that Australia does not play some part in trying to involve itself in SDI research at least. I am disappointed that the Government, in its analysis, has not seen fit to participate in research, as countries such as Japan and the United Kingdom have done and are doing. It is important that we play our role in the wider world scene, and I believe that it is important that we all understand that SDI is a research initiative at least in which Australia can play a role. Were we to do so, it would certainly enable us to feel that on the wider scene we were doing more to participate in the ANZUS relationship than we would in the somewhat limited area that Mr Dibb outlines in his report on force structure.

As far as the Budget analysis of the Minister is concerned, I want to address a range of matters. I think it is important that the people listening to this broadcast of the proceedings of the House today understand that the Government itself pays fringe benefits tax. Much of our debate in this Parliament last week and again today has been around the consequences of the fringe benefits tax. There is no doubt that the unintended consequences-to use the phrase of the Prime Minister-apply as much in defence as they do in any other area. Indeed, I understand that the Department of Defence, having budgeted originally for an FBT liability of $116m, has revised that down to about $70m; but there is still an FBT liability. The uncertainty of the Government's measures is no better illustrated by the fact that even a department of state of the Commonwealth does not know what its liability is. The more important thing from the defence perspective in terms of spending money is that it is going to be cut from the available funds within the defence budget.

When we look at the estimates we know that somewhere between $170m and $190m was cut from the Forward Estimates. We know that at the moment about $50m has been cut from operating costs. There is no indication in the Budget Papers where funding for the FBT liability is to come from, but there is a clear indication that operating costs have been cut in order to meet the costs of the FBT. The point of FBT-as with defence, so with everybody else in the community-is that it destroys the ability of the Department of Defence, as it does for individuals in this nation, to perform at their maximum level of efficiency. It withdraws funds from the Department of Defence for its operating level. If one has not got flying time, sailing time and training time, one's ability to perform one's defence task is reduced. The one area which is certainly suffering at the moment in the defence forces is their overall ability to exercise and to maintain personnel at the high level of efficiency that is necessary for them to undertake their jobs. There is little doubt that FBT will affect this further in the future.

Perhaps the most significant area of all those affecting the defence forces lies in the problems with personnel. The Minister has referred to it in his statement. He has not addressed the fact that we still have about 40,000 civilians for about 70,000 uniformed personnel. That ratio is much higher that it was during wartime. While it is true that factories and defence establishments are being reviewed both in terms of their performance and their capability, we have heard very little today about the relevance of that. For example, the Minister talked about spending $76m on the two follow-on destroyers building at Williamstown Dockyard in Victoria, but he has not said whether the agreements that were to be entered into at that place, I understand by last Monday, have in fact been signed. The reality is that both management and unions at Williamstown have needed to be brought into line. There is no doubt that they certainly have a very poor record for performance and unless they are able to meet the obligations that are part of the FFG contracts, the future of shipbuilding at their dockyard is very grave indeed.

It is true that the teeth to tail ratio in defence is a worrying aspect of the whole of this assessment made by the Minister of his defence budget. Indeed, one of the difficulties that I think the Minister does not seem to realise is that it is a matter not just of how much money is spent in defence but of the value we get for that dollar. I am concerned at the personnel end that while there has been the Hamilton report `Supporting Service Families' there has been too little done to address the very real problems of trying to maintain the morale of senior non-commissioned officers, particularly and middle level officers in the Defence Force.

The Minister has explained the high rate of resignations on, in part, the hump from the Vietnam period. In reality, a lot of factors have contributed to resignations. I believe one of them is the degree to which within the Services there is an opportunity for those who are now serving in responsible positions to be able to do the job for which they were trained and recruited. There are far too many disincentives affecting their families and themselves. The Hamilton report goes part of the way, but it has not yet been implemented. Too many personnel are being posted from one destination to another and finding their families are suffering because their children cannot move easily from one school to another. They do not get the travelling allowance that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) enjoys in order to be able to live in Canberra while saying his home is in Sydney. The reality is that many of those in the Services are totally disadvantaged regarding the education of their children and the employment of their wives. The circumstances of service men and women in 1986 cannot be seen in terms of the 1940s and 1950s. I believe it is time that the Minister sent a full reference to the Defence Force Remuneration Tribunal suggesting that there should be an examination into the comparability of pay and allowances in the Services and those that exist not only in civil employment but also in the Public Service itself. Certainly there are some areas where salaries might be comparable, but there is a lot more to it than just salaries. I think there is a real requirement for a greater comparison to be drawn and for a genuine attempt to be made to correct those disparities so that we can retain those whom it costs so much to train.

There is no doubt that the defence brain drain is really at a crisis level. At all levels and in all services highly trained personnel are leaving the ADF faster than they can be recruited, let alone trained. At the end of August over 620 male officers had resigned from the Defence Force during 1986, more than the total figure for the whole of 1985. In July and August alone the Royal Australian Air Force lost 22 pilots trained at a cost of more than $1m each-one-third of the number lost in the previous 12 months. Losses from the ADF, now running at almost 10 per cent per year, are now unsustainable if the quality of the Defence Force is to be preserved. If we had to retrain at any stage for a defence contingency there would be insufficient trained people to provide that training. The ADF is reaching the point where it has only one choice-cutting back on functions. I am afraid that the Army is already preparing to do just that. The Chief of the General Staff said recently that the only way out for the Army was to divert manpower from lower priority areas. He stated:

Last year we took a major cut out of the support areas-supply, transport, repair. The only way we can do this is to stop doing some things altogether and by starting to contract out to civil industry wherever we can.

I commend contracting out, but contracting out must be done on a basis where it is not going to weaken the structure or the capability of the defence forces. A senior RAAF officer warned in a detailed study this year that unless current RAAF losses were stemmed, the RAAF would have to curtail its functions. The former Flag Officer Commanding the Australian Fleet said in an interview published by Australian Associated Press on 25 September that in the four years since Labor's decision not to replace HMAS Melbourne, Navy strength had been cut from 17,500 to 15,500. He continued:
. . . and in the last 15 months, five ships, including the destroyers Yarra and Vampire, had been paid off earlier than planned.

The Government's response in the face of this crisis has been far too little, far too late. In his statement the Minister acknowledged the un- usually high resignation rates of officers. He has talked about the Hamilton report and the 5.9 per cent ADF pay rise. If we look at the 5.9 per cent pay rise, part of the problem will be realised. A cable classified `Staff in confidence' to the Royal Australian Navy headquarters in Canberra after the rise was announced in 1985, and which happened to fall off the back of a truck, stated:
Personnel reacted in a sober and polite manner but are deeply hurt. They expressed bitter disappointment and general discontent at the DFRT decision on both 5.9 per cent pay rise and retrospectivity.

The overwhelming consensus of opinion has been that the announced pay increase does not raise the pay level of members to that which they see earned by civilian contemporaries outside the service who receive penalty rates which we are only partially compensated for by service allowance.

There has been equal concern in the ADF at the Government's action in twice breaking a specific promise not to cut Defence Force retirement benefits and Defence Force retirement and death benefits: First, with the lump sum tax on superannuation; and then in this Budget-there is no mention of this in the Minister's statement-by the discounting of DFRB and DFDB increases. Unfortunately that 2 per cent discounting will be permanent and for ever after those who are potential or present recipients of those two benefits-DFRB or DFRDB-will be affected by that 2 per cent discount. There is concern at a whole range of petty attacks on the conditions of service that range from health care to Reserve pay. While the Minister very commendably talks about the restoration of the tax deduction on reserve personnel pay, it is not to take place until 1 January next year. Why on earth has the Government not implemented it immediately? Why defer it until then? The Government's limited response in the Hamilton report is just not enough. The Minister cannot get up in this House and try to take the credit for a range of defence procurement projects that were set in place by us and then claim that he cannot afford to pay service men and women enough to persuade them to stay.

There is no doubt that defence has been seriously affected by Labor's lopsided priorities. While I know the Minister has a genuine concern, many cuts have been introduced to salve the limousine Left and its flexible conscience. I am afraid the result is that there are for many personnel enormous difficulties which in 1986 are no longer sustainable. I identify just some of them: Education for children, the problems of transferring from one State to another and the problems that exist for service men and women in transferring from one house to another. While funds are being provided for housing, I do not believe the defence housing authority gives anywhere near the value for the defence dollar that we would get if we gave land and the opportunity to build to private contractors, and certainly if, instead of trying to refurbish old houses, there were a decision to allow for funds from the sale of existing sub-standard homes to be kept within the Defence Force-

TALK.START.PARA: —There is.

—At the moment in most instances those houses are refurbished at an inordinate cost-anything up to $30,000 or $40,000. If we let contracts for 100 or more houses we would get a lot better standard of house and so service men and women would be housed in a much more satisfactory way.

SPEECH.PARA: It is most important to understand that in 1986 generally throughout the work force far more two-income families exist than was the case a few years ago. Unfortunately in the Services, the ability of women to transfer from one billet to another and pick up a job such as the one they have just left is very much reduced. There are genuine management problems in trying to ensure that the families of service men and women are not disadvantaged because of the problems wives, or husbands, have in trying to find employment when moved to another billet. There is no doubt that the men and women of the Australian Defence Force are Australia's greatest asset and I am disappointed that the Minister has not given a higher priority to ensuring that their general terms and conditions of employment are brought up to those that exist in the general work force.

Another initiative in the Minister's statement relates to buying Australian. One of the real concerns I have about the Minister's whole administration is his failure to understand that buying Australian should also mean designing within Australia. There is a succession of projects in which the Minister, his Department or his defence advisers have seen fit to bypass altogether the capabilities of Australian engineers, Australian draftsmen and Australian designers. I give three recent illustrations, the first of which is the cancellation of project Waler. There is no doubt that the armoured personnel carrier, the M116, designed for northern European and northern American conditions, does not operate well in the dust and the heat of Australia. I believe it would have been far better had we tried to develop, with some flexibility in the terms and conditions of the project, a vehicle more suited to Australian conditions. Instead of that, project Waler has been scrapped, after significant funds had been spent on it. While the present APC vehicle might be suitable for training purposes, frankly I believe it to be no longer suitable for war. It is necessary to reinstate an APC program designed to produce a light mobile armoured vehicle for Australian conditions. There is no doubt that, while some of the criteria laid down may have needed amendment, to have scrapped the project altogether was no answer.

I refer secondly to the overseas sourcing of new small arms for the ADF. Any number of manufacturers have come to me to say that they have the ability to develop a new light weapon for the Australian Defence Force. I have fired one of these weapons. I know that the Owen gun worked very effectively during World War II, and I find it incredible that in 1986 we were not even prepared to accept the design of an Australian manufacturer for a new generation of light weapon for the Services. The third matter is the cancellation of the A10B Wamira trainer for the Royal Australian Air Force. This project-the terms and conditions of the project were determined by the RAAF-began in 1980 following a report by an industry study group. The same study group gained a contract for project definition. In July 1985 the Government opened the project to overseas competition. In December 1985 it abandoned the project. As much as $75m of taxpayers' funds were spent on that project, as well as $64m by the Australian Aircraft Consortium.

The Government has announced instead that it will buy the Swiss PC9 at a cost of $231m. Only 45 per cent of that money will be spent in Australia. At least 55 per cent of the money spent on the Wamira project would have been spent in Australia. The project would have been designed here. It would have enabled Australian aeronautical engineers to preserve their talents and to maintain the skills that have enabled them, over the years, to design some quite outstanding aircraft. No longer does it seem that the Government is concerned about Australian aircraft design in this country. The Wamira project would have generated about two million man hours of work in Australia; the PC9 will generate 1 1/2 million. Some 120 engineers were involved in Wamira, and 25 per cent have now left the industry. So much for that aspect of the Government's supporting buy Australian and export drives.
Another project has been brought to my attention. I read very briefly to the House a letter I have received from a designer and builder of small craft, dated 29 September this year:

For the past two years our company has been working on the design and development of a special forces assault boat for the Australian S.A.S. and Commando regiments. The design of this craft has been based on information we have received from special forces personnel, and therefore we can assume that in the main, our craft, which is known as the ``Seacat'', complies with the users requirements (S.A.S.). We have appended a copy of our design for your information.

We have recently been advised by the Australian Army that a number of craft for the S.A.S.'s role in Bass Strait are to be purchased from the United Kingdom at a price estimated to be twice that of our craft, which is 100% Australian designed and manufactured.

So the Minister produces this statement and produces high words, he talks about buying Australian and export drives, but he is doing nothing himself within the Australian Defence Force. There is every reason for us to design, build and manufacture, and the more so at a time when we have enormous difficulties in maintaining employment in our manufacturing sector. It is absolutely critical that we try to the maximum not only to manufacture and assemble here, not just to look at our offsets programs, but also to design and develop within Australia. We should use some part of our research and development budget to ensure, as is the case with the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, that to the maximum we integrate the benefits of the Government dollar and the private sector. The Australian defence manufacturers have done a great job over the years and there is no reason why they should not continue to do so.

Another part of this statement which concerns me is that part relating to the whole field of defence co-operation. The Minister talks about the amount of money that will be spent in the Pacific islands, Papua New Guinea and South East Asia. In relation to the money allocated to the Pacific island countries and Papua New Guinea, while some time ago I was concerned about the quality of the Pacific patrol boat, I have since had an opportunity to see it and I believe it to be an excellent craft and well suited to its purpose. However, I am worried that so much of the money allocated under the defence co-operation program to the Pacific island countries and Papua New Guinea is dedicated to that single project. We need to look at our wider role in the DCP and certainly within the Association of South East Asian Nations. I believe that, with common procurement of a range of defence equipment, it is possible for us to set up, in co-operation with those countries, a defence manufacturing capability that can meet their needs and ours, that it might be possible to extend into exports and that certainly would give us a far greater mutual defence interdependence at a time when we must work together rather than compete with each other and buy our designs and manufactured goods from abroad.

There is another aspect of this regional defence co-operation program which concerns me but which is not mentioned in the statement. I refer to defence attaches. Defence attaches are representatives of the uniformed Services who are posted to a range of Australian missions overseas. They do not come strictly within the field of the DCP but they are important in preserving some understanding and knowledge of defence outside this country. It is not only in the field of defence attaches that we, when in office, saw fit to provide defence postings abroad. On a number of occasions in this House I have referred to the Multinational Force and Observers in the Sinai and our belief that in our commitment to that group and in our staffing commitment that went with it Australia was doing a great deal to assist the nations of Israel and Egypt preserve peace on that Sinai frontier. That commitment was very well regarded by other elements of the MFO. It was a positive contribution on behalf of world peace. I regret the fact that this Government has withdrawn that element.

So too is the Government now withdrawing defence attaches. By the end of the year, defence attache staff serving at Australian missions overseas are to be cut by about 30 per cent, if a report in the Pacific Defence Reporter of October 1986 is to be believed. I am told that defence attaches are to be withdrawn from Islamabad, which office has been reporting on the war between Iran and Iraq and on the Soviet activities in Afghanistan. I would have thought it tremendously important to Australia to know what is going on in that part of the world, but the Government is to withdraw that defence attache. It is very pertinent on the day that the Prime Minister of India is visiting Australia that the defence attache is to be withdrawn from New Delhi. He reports on what is happening in Nepal. Of course, that whole northern boundary between India and China is of tremendous importance for the whole of central Asia. The defence attaches are also to be withdrawn from Bonn and Paris. While Bonn and Paris may not be immediately relevant for Australia's defence, we should remember that there are many aspects of the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation commitment and that France's Force de Frappe outside NATO has a tremendous relationship to the future stratagem of Australian defence force planning. Other posts affected are Tokyo and Manila, which will each lose an assistant attache; Seoul in Korea, which will lose a warrant officer; Jakarta and Port Moresby, which will each lose two defence operation program staff; London, which will lose two positions; and Washington, which will lose seven positions.

The reality is that there is a minimal number of people absolutely necessary in every overseas post. Equally, I commend to the Minister the thought that in those posts there seems to be a particular need for Australia still to maintain a defence presence. It is not a matter of our always being able to make a major contribution in such countries, but there is a great deal that we can learn; and there is certainly an opportunity for Australia to play a wider role with our allies in understanding how they approach defence issues and how their defence forces are structured. We can learn from them to the advantage of this nation.

There are many individual procurement matters in the statement that are worthy of comment. I do not intend to go through them all. It is worth noting that the Minister is still talking about yet another design for the surface ships. He refers to the project for the eight surface ships that were first mentioned in the Dibb report. I commend to him the thought that, the FFG having been brought into service and HMAS Darwin having proved such an effective and capable vessel, she being the fourth in line, having stabilisers and a stretched helicopter platform which makes her somewhat different from the earlier ships, although they are to be upgraded to that capability, there would seem to be an advantage in our looking at modifications to the FFG hull in order to meet whatever additional service ships might be called into play in the wider commitment of the RAN. To set up yet another design seems to me to be foolish in the extreme.

Part of the problem in the Australian Defence Force-not peculiarly in the Navy but certainly also in the Navy-has been the multiplicity of individually designed ships, all of which seem to have different engine systems and many of which have different sets of armaments. Some were originally oriented to the United Kingdom; now they are so much more oriented to the United States. There would be a great advantage both to shipbuilders and to those serving on board those ships if there were some greater standardisation of design and capability. I think it very necessary that we look at the FFG rather than just accept that we will go ahead and build yet another design. Instead of looking at another design for the eight surface ships, I suggest we should look at least at the FFG hull, with a different superstructure and perhaps different armaments, if that should be required.

Secondly, I notice that there is reference to the Seahawk and the Blackhawk and programs for their future expansion. The Seahawk and the Blackhawk were certainly the right choices by the Government for replacement helicopters. However, it is necessary that, as far as possible, we try to develop within the Seahawk an anti-submarine warfare capability that will allow it to play a role on our frigates so that our ships are not left with the notable lack of ASW performance that followed the fact that the Sea Kings are really no longer able to go to sea.

In the report there is reference to northern defence facilities, in respect of which the Opposition agrees with the Government on the areas where funds are being spent. However, in respect of his reference to the basing of the Blackhawks at Townsville, I say to the Minister that we on this side of the House believe it appropriate that the crews of the ground defence helicopters of the Services should wear an Air Force uniform but be under the command of the Army. We see no reason why they should be transferred to the Army, as I understand from some of the reports emanating from Defence may be the case. It seems to me that, while it is necessary that the command be retained with the Army, perhaps with the operational deployment force commander, the uniform worn should not be a matter that leads to the cost, as I understand it, of $60m or $70m in terms of replacing existing facilities.

The statement by the Minister opens doors in some areas. Unfortunately, it does not open sufficient doors and overall it has certainly neglected what we see as our prime concern for the well-being of the personnel of the Australian defence forces and their wives and families. A higher priority should have been given to that and we suggest to the Minister that, while a little has been done, much more needs to be done. I commend to him the suggestion of a further reference to the Defence Force Remuneration Tribunal to look at the comparability of service pay and conditions with those within the Public Service and the civil work force.

PETITION.TITLE: Closure of Post Office Agencies
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we strenuously object to the proposal that many post office agencies are to be closed. They provide a network of offices with postal and agency services to residential areas and small communities. We maintain that the purpose of post offices should be to serve the public for the variety of services they offer. They are a community centre particularly in country areas and if necessary they should be subsidised to retain them.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that whereas:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the Nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location on this planet Earth;
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. They know the Flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to the Flag will produce division in the Australian community.

Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will: Propose and pass a motion that ``the existing Australian National Flag be changed only with the approval of the Nation as expressed in a Referendum''.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Australian flag symbolises the continuity between Australia's past, its present and the future;

That the presence of the Union Jack on the flag represents not a subservience to Britain, but a reminder of our inheritance of the fruits of hundreds of years of struggle for individual liberty against the forces of tyranny and oppression;
Nonetheless recognises the rights of Australians should they wish as a people to change the design of their flag.
Your petitioners humbly pray that no change be made to the Australian flag except with the consent of the people in a referendum.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned, are deeply concerned at the impact of the new Fringe Benefits Tax on the following grounds:
1. Its severe and damaging effect on business confidence, investment and incentive, especially in the rural, mining and small business sectors.
2. Its capacity to seriously worsen unemployment through the additional costs its imposes.
3. Its extremely negative impact on the competitiveness of export industries at a time when the nation desperately needs to improve its trading performance.

4. In that it may compel many honest and decent citizens to defy the Tax in order to preserve their livelihoods, their businesses and the jobs of their employees, thus causing hardship, the breakdown of respect for the law and discord within the community.
We therefore most earnestly petition you to repeal the Fringe Benefits Tax legislation forthwith.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
We, the undersigned, are seriously concerned about the impact of the Fringe Benefits Tax on the following grounds:
1. It is unjust for any person to be liable for tax on benefits received by another person.
2. Compliance with FBT will increase administrative costs for all employers including Local, State and Federal government departments.
3. FBT is an inefficient tax, which will require the Tax Office to employ an army of bureaucrats.
4. FBT is inequitable because liability arises regardless of capacity to pay.
5. The FBT laws are extremely complex.
We therefore most earnestly petition you to repeal the Fringe Benefits Tax legislation forthwith.
Your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

3. Its extremely negative impact on the competitiveness of export industries at a time when the nation desperately needs to improve its trading performance.

4. In that it may compel many honest and decent citizens to defy the Tax in order to preserve their livelihoods, their businesses and the jobs of their employees, thus causing hardship, the breakdown of respect for the law and discord within the community.
We therefore most earnestly petition you to repeal the Fringe Benefits Tax Legislation forthwith.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that the Fringe Benefits Tax is an iniquitous and unjust impost which will further damage the Australian economy and further increase costs to employers.
The Tax will:
(1) further increase the level of unemployment;
(2) increase the administrative costs and overheads for business and Government;
(3) particularly disadvantage small businesses and farmers; and
(4) act as a disincentive to those who are the most productive and skilled;
and we the undersigned call upon the Government to immediately repeal the Fringe Benefits Tax.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
The fringe benefits tax will cause hardship to business throughout Australia, especially in the already severely depressed rural sector and in the motor vehicle industry.

The fringe benefits tax will be a disincentive to employment and worse, will result in additional unemployment. The economy of this country would best be served by policies that lightened the tax burden, not increased it, that encouraged enterprise, not stifled it and stimulated growth, development and jobs, not prevented it.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House will repeal this Legislation and your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowances and Spouse Rebate
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:
Graduated family allowances are of important assistance to families with more than one child.
All family allowances, whether for one, two, three, or more children, have not kept pace with inflation.
There are suggestions that all family allowances should be paid at the one flat rate. This would severely disadvantage families with more than one child.
There are also suggestions that the dependent spouse rebate be reduced or removed. This would represent another blow to the family unit.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should:
Ask the Federal Government to increase the value of existing family allowance payments, and
Reject any moves to change the payments to a flat rate or to tamper with the spouse rebate;
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Downer,Mr Duncan,Mr Hawker and Mr Kent.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowances and Spouse Rebate
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. We, the undersigned plead that the Parliament implement pro-family policies. In particular we appeal for:
1. the retention of the present graduated assessment system for payment of the Family Allowance;
2. indexation of the Family Allowance in order to keep pace with inflation;

3. an increase of 3.7% in the Family Allowance benefit to return it to 11.5% of the Average Award Wage (making it similar in value to the 11.5% of the Basic Wage when Child Endowment was first introduced by the Chifley Government in 1941).
4. retention of the Dependent Spouse Rebate and the amount of the Dependent Spouse Rebate adjusted so that it is equal in value to the tax-free threshold allowed when calculating taxable income.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you will give this matter earnest consideration and your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowances and Spouse Rebate
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That taxpayers with dependent children have been gravely disadvantaged by a serious decline in the level of recognition provided in the taxation system for the costs of maintaining a family, in particular.
The failure to index family allowances which has resulted in an erosion of more than 50% in their real value since May 1976;
The abolition of family allowances for dependants who have turned 18, even those still at school;
The abolition of concessional tax rebates for education and other expenses.

That this erosion in horizontal tax equity has placed an intolerable financial burden on many larger families, particularly those on middle incomes who fail to qualify for means-tested benefits such as TEAS but whose living standards are now well below average due to heavy expenses on necessities such as education, housing, food and clothing.
Your Petitioners humbly pray that:
family allowances be restored to the 1976 value (in real terms), and indexed according to the CPI;
the dependent spouse rebate be retained;
the Federal Government take urgent measures to restore equitable provisions in the taxation system through the introduction of family income splitting.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowances and Spouse Rebate
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. We, the undersigned plead that the Parliament implement pro-family policies. In particular we appeal for:
1. the retention of the present graduated assessment system for payment of the Family Allowance;
2. indexation of the Family Allowance in order to keep pace with inflation;

3. an increase of 3.7% in the Family Allowance benefit to return it to 11.5% of the Average Award Wage (making it similar in value to the 11.5% of the Basic Wage when Child Endowment was first introduced by the Chifley Government in 1941).
4. retention of the Dependent Spouse Rebate and the amount of the Dependent Spouse Rebate adjusted so that it is equal in value to the tax-free threshold allowed when calculating taxable income.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you will give this matter earnest consideration and your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Film Censorship Board
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable the Speaker, and Members of the House of Representatives of the Parliament of Australia assembled. We, the undersigned, plead that Parliament will legislate, or act in accordance with the present legislation to replace the current members of the Film Censorship Board who have admitted to Senator Harradine on 12th December, 1984 as reported in the Senate Select Committee on Video Material, (see attached extracts), that they are not applying either the blasphemy or obscenity tests as required under the provisions of the Customs (Cinematograph Films) Regulations, and that these persons be replaced by persons who will apply these and the other related test in accordance with the said Regulations.
Your petitioners humbly pray that you will give this matter your earnest consideration, and your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Campbell and Mr Dawkins.

PETITION.TITLE: Film Censorship Board
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable the Speaker, and Members of the House of Representatives of the Parliament of Australia assembled. We the undersigned, plead that Parliament will revoke and replace with family-oriented persons, all appointments to the Film Censorship Board prior to 1985, and thus improve the nurturing home environment of Australia's children, because we have read pages 149 to 152 of the Official Hansard Transcript of Evidence to the Select Committee on Video Material, and we ask you to read it.
Your petitioners humbly pray that you will give this matter your earnest consideration, and your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Radioactive Substances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth. We most strongly oppose the process of Food Irradiation by radioactive Cobalt 60 or any other radioactive substance.

We oppose the introduction of regulations that will facilitate the food irradiation process by State Governments. We express our deep concern at this attempt to extend the use of radioactive substances and exposure of workers to radiation.

We call on the Government to immediately ban the importation of radioactive Cobalt 60 or other radioactive substances and to immediately disallow the regulations that permit the irradiation of food here in Australia.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Kent,Mr Milton and Mr Scott.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Honourable Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that whereas they are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.

Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will give a speedy passage to the Flags Act Amendment Bill which provides that the Australian National Flag can only be changed by a Referendum.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Cunningham and Ms Mayer.

PETITION.TITLE: Social Justice, Equity and Redistribution of Wealth
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of Australia, hereby petition the Prime Minister as Leader of the Australian Labor Party in Government in Australia and humbly showeth that:

The voting public of Australia did in March 1983 and again in December 1984 vote as a majority for the election of a Labor Government who did claim to stand for social justice, equity and redistribution.
That the said voters sincerely believe that a contract was entered into in voting for a Labor Government with democratic socialist principles.

That there is an erosion of support for the pensioners, the unemployed, the aged, the sick and the working class of Australia, while the lot of the privileged class, the banks, the oil companies, and the money-changers continues to improve.

Your Petitioners call on the Australian Labor Government to implement those policies and follow those principles of social justice, equity and redistribution which the majority of Australians voted for in 1983 and in 1984, and to adopt an immediate programme that will transfer the current economic burden to those better able to carry it.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Kent and Mr Scott.

PETITION.TITLE: Changes to Veterans' Entitlements
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that persistent rumour suggest that the Hawke Government intends to reduce Government expenditure by contracting or eliminating programs for war veterans and war widows.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Hawke Government honour its commitment and that of previous Governments to ex-servicemen and women by:
Ensuring no additional cut-backs will be made to the portfolio of Veterans' Affairs.
Review the previous cut-backs in such areas as the travel allowances, dental scheme and repatriation pharmaceutical benefits scheme.
Proceed with abolishing more stringent conditions applying to the granting of the TPI pension.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that the Bill of Rights is not supported by the people of Australia, and calls on the Government to delay proclamation of the Bill until all matters of contention are settled by national referenda, and that:
(1) Matters of States rights, property rights, rights of the newborn, the right not to belong to unions, among other issues, have not been submitted to the people of Australia to decide, and that:
(2) No Australian Bill of Rights should depend on any foreign convention for its basis in Australian law.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, Wollongong Area Office
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:
That we the citizens of the Illawarra Region condemn the decision to close the Wollongong office of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs,
and that we respectfully request that this decision be reversed immediately.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: `Fair Go for Women' Survey
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that the 1986 Census deprived housewives of the right to record their occupation and instead forced them to give the negative response: ``No, did not have a job''.
That the 1986 Census could have been used, at no extra cost to taxpayers, to give a GENUINE ``Fair Go'' to ALL women to record their views on the government's National Agenda for Women.

That coinciding with the 1986 Census, the Office of the Status of Women is conducting a costly, selective survey titled: ``A FAIR GO FOR WOMEN''. This survey requires no identification of respondents, making the results of the survey highly suspect since it is known that various groups and individuals have obtained bulk supplies of the brochure, while the majority of women are not aware that their views are being sought by the Government.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, will restore to the Census a category for Housewives, and that the ``FAIR GO FOR WOMEN'' survey will be recognised as a costly exercise of dubious value in determining the real views of Australian women, as this should be done through the Census, or a Referendum held in conjunction with the next Federal Election to minimise costs, and to give ALL women a genuine ``Fair Go''.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will every pray.

PETITION.TITLE: English as a Second Language Program
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and Honourable Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned residents of Australia respectfully showeth:

By cutting ESL funding and eliminating funding for community languages and multicultural education you have attacked tens of thousands of Australian children. You have condemned these children with limited English to gross educational inequality and very dim prospects for their future.
On behalf of these children we call on you to remove this new discrimination which your budget has guaranteed by immediately restoring ESL and Multicultural education funding.

PETITION.TITLE: Extradition (Foreign States) Act 1966
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned residents of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the humble petitioners are gravely concerned about recent changes in the Extradition (Foreign States) Act of 1966 which deny basic rights which have been a cornerstone of the English and Australian law for over seven hundred years. We are speaking of the right to be presumed innocent until proven guilty and the right of an individual to defend himself against his accusers. This concern has come to light during recent extradition proceedings against Messrs Hempel and Etheredge in Western Australia.

We are concerned that because judicial protection of these basic rights has been excluded from the Act refugees migrants Australian overseas travellers and visitors are at risk when they have been to (or come from) countries where the norms and practices of human rights and civil liberties are below traditionally accepted Australian standards.

We the undersigned petitioners, therefore urge the government to re-examine the Extradition (Foreign States) Act as amended in 1985 and amend the current Act so that the rights of the accused are once again judicially protected in Australia.

In addition, we urge the government to refrain from entering into any further extradition treaties or proceedings under the current Act until the process of re-examination and amendment of the Act has occurred.
And your Petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned electors of Australia respectfully showeth;
That the Government should cancel the Fringe Benefits Tax they intend to impose on businesses throughout Australia because;
1. The tax discriminates against charitable organisations, sports clubs, private schools and religious organisations;
2. The tax will mean employees around Australia will suffer reductions in their remuneration packages;
3. The Bill places another impossible burden of paperwork on small business;
4. The Bill is absurd in its application to Government employees, who now constitute 32% of the workforce.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament House.
The petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Bill of Rights is a dangerous piece of legislation which gives us no new legally enforceable rights;
That the Bill of Rights leaves out vital rights such as the right not to belong to a trade union, the right to own private property, the right to a private education;
That the Bill of Rights gives dangerous new powers to a Federal Government Commission to investigate in private, without legal representation and with criminal penalties for refusing to co-operate;
That the Bill of Rights deals with our rights; therefore we, the people, should say whether we want it by a referendum.

Your petitioners humbly pray that you repeal the Bill of Rights legislation and not restrict the individual freedoms of Australians and its present justice system, nor in any underhand way centralise power in our three tier system of Government.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Maranoa electorate respectfully showeth that:
The current Government's Bill of Rights seeks to make changes in the constitutional balance in Australia by intruding into the affairs of individuals and of State and local Governments.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to repeal the Bill of Rights legislation and not restrict the individual freedoms of Australians and its present justice system, nor in any underhand way centralise power in our three tier system of Government.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The Petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Bill of Rights is a dangerous piece of legislation which gives us no new legally enforceable rights
That the Bill of Rights leaves out vital rights such as the right not to belong to a trade union, the right to own private property, the right to a private education
That the Bill of Rights gives dangerous new powers to a Federal Government Commission to investigate in private, without legal representation and with criminal penalties for refusing to co-operate
That the Bill of Rights deals with our rights; therefore we, the people, should say whether we want it by a referendum.
Your petitioners therefore pray that you will oppose the Bill of Rights, support Liberal amendments to improve it in case it is passed, and pledge to repeal it should it become law.

PETITION.TITLE: Fuel Prices
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows that the Hawke Government should:
1. Pass on the full benefit of low international oil prices;
2. Not increase or extend fuel taxes; and
3. Maintain its tax cut commitments.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Hawke Government honour its commitment to the Import Parity Pricing policy.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions: Assets Test
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That in the light of the Labor Government's failure to act to correct the many anomalies in the Assets Test on pensions brought to its notice, the Labor Government's legislation should be repealed before it has an unduly unfair impact on pensioners.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should immediately seek the repeal of the Labor Government's iniquitous and unfair Assets Test.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Radio Station 3EA
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia of Albanian back-ground respectfully showeth:
We most strongly oppose the use of the `Special Broadcasting Service' and the taxpayers funds for nationalist political purposes.

We are deeply concerned that the existing Albanian program on Radio 3EA Melbourne is not meeting the needs of the community. It is being used against its interests, as well as the interests of the broader Australian society.
We respectfully believe that such use of public facilities undermines Australian principles of multi-culturalism and has a damaging effect on community relations.

Your petitioners therefore, strongly urge the Government to take immediate action to ensure that the present announcers of the Albanian program are removed and replaced with community representatives.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Test Ban
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
This Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that-

(1) A cessation of the testing of nuclear weapons would break the cycle of research, development and deployment of nuclear weapons and prevent the acquisition of new and ever more lethal weapons of mass destruction. It would thus be a major and significant step towards ending the arms race and beginning the disarmament process; and
(2) The Soviet Union has extended its unilateral moratorium on nuclear weapons testing until 6 August this year and has again invited the United States to cease its nuclear testing program.
Your petitioners therefore urge the Australian Government to put the strongest pressure on the United States Government to join the Soviet Union's nuclear test ban.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Free Zones
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of citizens of Australia shows-

That the people of New Zealand and the New Zealand Government have given an example to the world in their efforts to achieve a nuclear free South Pacific, and such decision being endorsed by the people at a general election.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Australian Government support the principled stand taken by the New Zealand Government and urges it to condemn any efforts by the U.S. Government to impose economic or other sanctions on New Zealand in retaliation for their stand on nuclear vessels.
We further urge the Australian Government to urgently implement its policy to promote the development of zones of peace and nuclear free zones in the Indian and Pacific Oceans.

PETITION.TITLE: Prescription Drugs for Pensioners
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth that your petitioners wish that all medicines prescribed by a registered Medical Practitioner be made available free of charge by the Government to all pensioners for the following reasons:
1. The enormous cost of some drugs, including pain relieving ones, not at present on the `free list'.
2. That certain drugs essential for permanently disabled, such as epileptics are at present being charged for and therefore present a great financial burden to the pensioner.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will consider our wishes. And your petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Education Administration Fee
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable Speaker and the Honourable Members of the House of Representatives in the assembled Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia. We the humble petitioners at Bendigo College of Advanced Education and from within the community served by the College, respectfully showeth:
That the introduction of an administration charge of $250 for higher education students in Appropriation Bill 1986-87 (Volume 1, p. 98) is a regressive step for the education system;
That the introduction of an administration charge will force students to withdraw from studies and thereby destroy the opportunity for them to complete their education;
That the administration charge is a form of tuition fees and as such destroys the principle of free education for all;
That it is contrary to ALP policy which states that the party `will maintain the provision of free tertiary education'.
We, the humble petitioners hereby request you to amend the Appropriation Bill 1986-87, so that the system of free education for all students will continue.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Education Administration Fee
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable Speaker and the Honourable Members of the House of Representatives in the assembled Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia. We the humble petitioners at Ballarat College of Advanced Education Student Union, in the Federal Electorate of Ballarat, respectfully showeth:
That the introduction of an administration charge of $250 for higher education students in Appropriation Bill 1986-87 (Volume 1, p. 98) is a regressive step for the education system;
That the introduction of an administration charge will force students to withdraw from studies and thereby destroy the opportunity for them to complete their education;
That the administration charge is a form of tuition fees and as such destroys the principle of free education for all;
We, the humble petitioners hereby request you to amend the Appropriation Bill 1986-87, so that the system of free education for all students will continue.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Education Administration Fee
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable Speaker and the Honourable Members of the House of Representatives in the assembled Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia. We the humble petitioners at Deakin University, in the Federal Electorate of Corangamite, respectfully showeth:
That the introduction of an administration charge of $250 for higher education students in Appropriation Bill 1986-87 (Volume 1, p. 98) is a regressive step for the education system;
That the introduction of an administration charge will force students to withdraw from studies and thereby destroy the opportunity for them to complete their education;
That the administration charge is a form of tuition fees and as such destroys the principle of free education for all;
We, the humble petitioners hereby request you to amend the Appropriation Bill 1986-87, so that the system of free education will continue.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Education Administration Fee
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable Speaker and the Honourable Members of the House of Representatives in the assembled Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia. We the humble petitioners at Phillip Institute of Technology Student Union, in the Federal Electorate of Wills, respectfully showeth:
That the introduction of an administration charge of $250 for higher education students in Appropriation Bill 1986-87 (Volume 1, p. 98) is a regressive step for the education system;
That the introduction of an administration charge will force students to withdraw from studies and thereby destroy the opportunity for them to complete their education;
That the administration charge is a form of tuition fees and as such destroys the principle of free education for all;
We, the humble petitioners hereby request you to amend the Appropriation Bill 1986-87, so that the system of free education for all students will continue.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Education Administration Fee
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. This Petition of the Undersigned Citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

1. The introduction of an administrative charge for annual enrolment will restrict access to higher education for a range of disadvantaged groups, particularly women, rural dwellers and some low income earners.
2. Students will be deterred from study because of the probable escalation in the charge in future Budgets, prohibiting students' ability to plan the long term costs of their education.

3. The introduction of an administrative charge is contrary to the education provisions of the ALP/ACTU Accord and ALP policy which states that the party ``will maintain the provision of free tertiary education.''
Your petitioners therefore pray that the annual administrative charge for higher education students not be introduced and that subsequent funding shortfalls be met from Government tax revenue.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: English as a Second Language Program
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned residents of Australia respectfully showeth:
We the undersigned residents of Australia totally reject any move to cut funding to Australia-wide English as a Second Language program in schools.
We request that the Australian government restore funding to the 1985 level in the 1986-87 budget.

PETITION.TITLE: Secondary Allowances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled.

We, the undersigned citizens of Western Australia call on the Commonwealth Government to reverse recent decisions which deny Secondary Allowances to Year 11 students under the age of 16 years and making such allowances directly payable to students on attaining the age of 16.
This request is made on the basis that:
(i) Education Benefits as part of income support benefits generally are a Commonwealth responsibility under the constitution.

(ii) It is the right of parents with children in Year 11 in Western Australia to receive the same benefits as parents with children at the equivalent stage of their education in other parts of Australia irrespective of their age.
(iii) This decision by the Commonwealth Government will impact most unfairly on the capacity of low income families in Western Australia to keep their children at school in Years 11 and 12.

(iv) Direct payment of the allowance to 16 year olds will make it easier for young people to leave home and bring more pressure on State Authorities to find alternative accommodation for them at the community and taxpayers' expense.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you will give this matter earnest consideration, and your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Capital Gains
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Richmond electorate respectfully showeth that:

Labor's Capital Gains Tax is standing in the way of economic development on the Far North Coast, a region with great potential for further growth and renowned for the enterprise and initiative of its local community.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Repeal its anti-business anti-farming and anti-individual Capital Gains Tax.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Western Sydney State University
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of New South Wales respectfully showeth:

That they strongly support the establishment of the Western Sydney State University as recommended in the Parry report and call upon the House to establish the Western Sydney State University in conjunction with the New South Wales Government.
And your petitioners, as is duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Western Sydney State University
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

The petition of certain residents of the State of New South Wales draws to the attention of the House the Report of the Ministerial Committee to Review the Structure of Higher Education in Western Sydney which recommends the establishment in 1987 of a Western Sydney State University along lines detailed in that report.

Your petitioners therefore request that the Commonwealth Government acts promptly to rectify the serious deficiencies in Higher Education in the Western Sydney Region by taking all actions necessary to enable the New South Wales Government to establish the University.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

The petition of certain residents of the Northern Territory of Australia draws to the attention of the House that the Fringe Benefits Tax Legislation recently passed by Parliament is unfair and will prejudice the current working conditions of all Territorians.
1. It will increase both personal and company taxation.
2. It will undermine employment levels through reducing profitability and international competiveness of industry.
3. It will result in price increases.
4. It will force employers to withdraw voluntary incentives to employees paid over and above existing payments.
5. It endangers stable industrial relations because of the potential for forced withdrawal of Fringe Benefits.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the House take such action as is necessary to rescind the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Act 1986, the Fringe Benefits Tax Act 1986, the Fringe Benefits Tax (Application to the Commonwealth) Act 1986 and the Fringe Benefits Tax (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 1986.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Capital Gains
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Victoria respectfully showeth:
That all legitimate business expenses incurred in earning or producing assessable income should be allowable deductions.
That the proposed Capital Gains Tax is an unwarranted burden on the rural sector, which will severely affect its long-term viability.
That the delay by the Government in introducing the legislation into Parliament is causing confusion and hindering farmers in the organisation of their affairs.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the Government introduces the Capital Gains Tax legislation without delay and that the Australian Democrats join with the Opposition to defeat the proposed legislation.

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium Sales to France
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned, respectfully showeth that we, the people of Victoria would like to remind you of your moral duty in regard to your decision to sell Uranium to France, against ALP Policy.
The French are still nuclear testing in the South Pacific, despite world wide protests. We therefore call on you to reverse the decision to sell Uranium to France.

PETITION.TITLE: Release of Documents
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Australia in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned George Joseph Nutman, Solicitor of the Supreme Court of the State of New South Wales, of 2 O'Connell Street, Sydney in the said State respectfully showeth:

1. Your petitioner is a solicitor acting on behalf of Marlew Mining Pty Limited in proceedings brought against it by various persons of Australian Aboriginal ancestry in the Supreme Court of New South Wales and the District Court of New South Wales claiming damages.

2. The House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs, at the request of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, the Honourable A. C. Holding, M.H.R., enquired into the effects of asbestos mining on the Baryulgil community.
3. In October 1984 the Chairman of the Committee the Honourable G. L. Hand, M.H.R., tabled the Report of the Committee in the House of Representatives.
4. During the hearings of the Committee certain photographs, letters, plans and a number of documents were received in evidence from one Gerald Francis Burke.
5. I am instructed that most or all of the material received in evidence from the said Gerald Francis Burke comprised records kept by Marlew Mining Pty Limited and was the property of that Company.

6. It has been brought to the attention of my client that the Aboriginal Legal Service Limited which acts on behalf of most of the plaintiffs in the proceedings brought against the Company has petitioned for the release of the said documents to it for the purpose of conducting the proceedings.

7. Marlew Mining Pty Limited has commenced proceedings in the Supreme Court of New South Wales against Gerald Francis Burke and the Aboriginal Legal Service being matter No. 16057 of 1986 seeking an order that the said documents, plans and photographs be delivered up to it.
8. It is necessary for the documents to be before the Supreme Court when the matter proceeds so that the Court can consider the right of Marlew Mining Pty Limited to possession.

9. The proceedings were before Master Sharpe of the Supreme court of New South Wales on the 25th day of July, 1986 when Master Sharpe gave leave to Marlew Mining Pty Limited to appoint a return date for a subpoena addressed to the Clerk of the House of Representatives requiring the production of the documents at the Supreme Court, King Street, Sydney.
10. Your Petitioner therefore humbly prays that this Honourable House will grant leave:

(a) To serve a subpoena on the Clerk of the House of Representatives requiring the production of the various photographs letters plans and documents received in evidence from Mr Gerald Francis Burke at the Supreme Court, Queen's Square, Sydney.

(b) That the said photographs, letters, plans and documents be released into the custody of the Supreme Court of New South Wales for the purpose of determining the issues raised in matter No. 16057 of 1986 concerning the rights to possession and ownership thereof.
And your petitioner, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
