DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker has received a letter from the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The confusion, frustration and high cost burden on the community arising from the Government's muddled decision making and appalling administration of the Fringe Benefits Tax.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carlton The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer (Mr Keating) has come back from another one of his overseas visits during which he tried to convince people that the Australian economy is better than it is. He has come back to the most appalling mess in taxation that this country has ever seen. This month, from 1 October, hundreds of thousands of business taxpayers, large and small, and tens of thousands of farmers are all required to submit a fringe benefits tax return with a cheque. They have to have that in, initially it was said, by 28 October. That date has been extended by a miserable two weeks. These taxpayers have to pay the tax; but they do not know what tax because, despite the fact that we had 139 pages of legislation, 176 pages of explanatory memorandum, 69 pages of explanatory notes sent out to business, another pamphlet on the fringe benefits tax and farmers, and a very expensive video which is now out of date--
—With Richard Carleton.

—Yes, with Richard Carleton doing the interviews. Despite all that, the people who are required to submit a very complicated tax return-originally by 28 October but now with a miserable two weeks extension-do not know what tax they have to pay. This became crystal clear when the Treasurer was away, despite the denials that he had made over a series of months.

SPEECH.PARA: What exactly has been going on here? The Treasurer, obviously, is desperate to collect the money. He has spent the money already with excessive spending over three years. In his Budget he has already put up the tax in total by $1 1/2 billion. He already has a system of phoney tax cuts coming into operation in December which will leave small to middle income earners worse off. So he is obviously desperate to get more money. But he cannot tell the Australian Taxation Office and the taxpayers themselves exactly on what basis this tax is supposed to be paid. All I can tell honourable members is that out there there is confusion, frustration, waste and cost. Time is being spent, and time means money. There is rage and fury out there, and the honourable members on the other side of the House know it.

It is a mess of this Treasurer's own creation. He has only himself to blame. He did not get into this tax because he lost out on option C at the Taxation Summit. He cannot blame the unions for this. This tax was in his original recommendations. It was in option A, which was part of option C. The Treasurer said at the Taxation Summit: `I want the fringe benefits tax and, in addition, I want a broadly based consumption tax'. He did not get the second, but he got what he wanted in the first-if, indeed, it is what he really wanted. I do not think that he understood the first thing of what he was asking for. Anyone with business experience would know that this tax was unworkable. The Treasurer might be at home spending most of his time being duchessed in the board rooms of the big finance houses, or being flown around in helicopters that are owned by his millionaire friends, and he might be at home with his First Empire clocks-I do not know in which residence-but he has not a clue about what every ordinary sales representative does every day in his car. He does not understand all the paper work that he has put upon the sales representative. He has no idea of what it is like to struggle for survival on a farm at the moment; he has not a clue. He has no idea of what it is like for a small business family that has committed all its assets-the home, business premises and any other assets the family has-to borrow in order to build a business. These are people who have committed their own effort and that of their families to make a business succeed, people for whom every dollar is important--

TALK.START.PARA: —You were born with a silver spoon. What are you talking about?

—The honourable member says that I was born with a silver spoon in my mouth. The honourable member had better just go and look at the facts. There are more people with silver spoons on the other side of the House than there are on this side of the House. All I can say is that the representatives of the party that claims to stand for working people draw farther and farther away from its grass roots, and it is quite clear in this debate that they have not a clue about what ordinary Australia is doing. The person who is farthest away from ordinary Australia is the Treasurer, who has just come back from his overseas trip.

SPEECH.PARA: The people who are working in their small businesses, the farmers who are trying to make their farms survive and the representatives who are going around in their cars trying to sell goods and services are all rorters and cheats as far as this Treasurer is concerned. Meanwhile, he has double standards on his travelling allowance claims. He is quite prepared to attack all these small people and at the very same time indulge in very dubious claims indeed with regard to travelling allowance. All I can say is that there are double standards from this Treasurer all the way. He cannot see that a log book in the representative's car is the last straw. He cannot see that $50 a week fringe benefits tax on a farm is a desperate thing if sales for farm products are running out and if costs are driven higher and higher by trade union action. A sum of $50 a week is petty cash for this Treasurer, but it is make or break for a farm that is making no income. Yet he has put an additional burden of $50 a week or more-in most cases more-on farmers through the fringe benefits tax. When these things have been drawn to his attention, what has been his reaction? It has been to dismiss them with contempt, in a pigheaded fashion, with arrogance; he has been hectoring, abusive and hypocritical.

It is not as if the Treasurer has had no warning. He has had warnings from everybody. The National Farmers Federation sent him a list of 106 questions and still has not had adequate replies. The Confederation of Australian Industry has written to the Treasurer and made representations. The Business Council of Australia, the Australian Federation of Employers, the miners, small business-all the representative groups-have made it absolutely clear that he has an unworkable and unfair tax on his hands, and he dismisses them with contempt. The Prime Minister, we are told, has had 4,500 letters complaining about the tax and, presumably, these have all been passed on to the poor hapless Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Treasurer (Mr Hurford), the Minister whose job it is to write farewell Bob tax replies to people.

The Australian Labor Party is against this tax. For God's sake, the Treasurer says that he does not know where the problems are. The Labor Party early on, including Premier Bannon last year, complained about the fringe benefits tax on motor cars, but the most important breaking of the ranks occurred in June, about a month after the tax had been introduced in this House. Labor Premier Burke of Western Australia, who is not even coming up to an election, said:

The package goals of fairness, freedom from distortion of economic activity, and stimulation of economic growth are not met in remote areas, and Commonwealth estimates of the costs and benefits of the package are in error . . . The tax package effectively discriminates against remote-area located families.

The next cri de coeur-in Queensland there is an election coming up and on 25 June it was expected-came from Mr Neville Warburton, the Queensland Opposition Leader, who hit out at the fringe benefits tax, calling it `an administrative nightmare'. He termed some aspects of it as `ridiculous' and said it read `as if some bureaucrat down there had gone mad'. It was not any bureaucrat that had gone mad; it was Napoleon over here. He was the one who brought it in, and he was the one who was determined, regardless of how cold it was in Moscow, to continue and impose it on everybody. Then there was a bit of quiet, but on 24 July 1986 Mr Burke said that things had gone awry since the fringe benefits tax was introduced. He said:
There is no question about that and certainly there have been problems involved in complying with the tax, the completion of the administration and the impact of the tax.
`Mutiny' said the Treasurer on 8 August. He said:

We didn't fight for this thing to see it squandered by some pressure group getting in touch with a Labor leader's office. I mean we are not going to change this thing. We're not changing the fringe benefits tax, it's here to stay. It's a total furphy, a total furphy. The Government is not going to change this tax.
However, the Prime Minister, ever the one to waver a bit in the breeze, showed signs of doubt. On 10 August he said:
If in the administration of the fringe benefits tax we find there are some aspects of the administration that are less than perfect, of course we will be prepared to change those things.
That ever helpful Premier of New South Wales, Mr Barrie Unsworth, always ready to lend a helping hand to his Federal colleagues, said--

TALK.START.PARA: —Who chose him?
—We know who chose him, the gentleman opposite, and he is now having to live with it. Barrie Unsworth said:

SPEECH.PARA: Quite clearly what's come out of the fringe benefits proposal is an administrative nightmare.

That is quite correct. He called on the Government to make the tax administratively easier and said he believed that, instead of the fringe benefits tax, the Government should have introduced a broadly based consumption tax, which Unsworth's mates had skewered at the time. But one must bear in mind that the fringe benefits tax was already in the package that the Treasurer was asking for at the Summit. The Prime Minister was stiffening up a little that day after Barrie's statement, and said:
No, we will not change it.

However, more Labor Premiers have come on to the scene. Premier Bannon of South Australia, on 12 August, said that it had `gone a bit further than the legislation or the intention'. That is interesting, is it not? Mr John Cain, Premier of Victoria, finally flushed out of his hole, said that it was `cumbersome and heavy-handed'. He said:
If there are better ways of handling it, then I would certainly support that.
Against this rebellion we have Napoleon back on the deck--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! If the honourable member is referring to the Treasurer, he should use his correct title.
—I certainly cannot refer to him by the name of his electorate because he never goes there. On 12 August the Treasurer said:

SPEECH.PARA: There's not going to be any administrative changes-that's it.

The Prime Minister was stiffening up a bit then, or perhaps he was starting to weaken when he said `We are going to keep the substance of the tax', but that he would see whether there were better ways of doing it. The Treasurer again said:
There are no anomalies or defects in the . . . tax.
The cat was let out of the bag by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), who said what everybody thought throughout the country: He said:

I don't want to debate the technicalities of the fringe benefits tax, but I've seen my own form from the Department of the Senate that I have to fill in, and I think it's horrifying. It's too difficult for me, and I appreciate, for that reason, why it's difficult for others.

At this stage the Treasurer went overseas-and who was in charge? It was Old Silver and Moo, Don Quixote and Sancho Panza. When it was pointed out that everybody, including Senator Button, knew that this tax was a total and absolute mess and failure, the Prime Minister said that he would inquire into the unintended consequences of the tax. He did that while the Treasurer was abroad, but the Treasurer in London dismissed it by saying that this was a sideshow. The Treasurer has come back to a sideshow which will run on and on until this Government is out of office, and until these 139 pages have gone lock, stock and barrel, together with the 176 pages of explanatory memorandum, the video, all the explanatory booklets and the 115 pages of statements in which the Taxation Commissioner tried to explain the damn thing. It is a mess, it is hopeless, it has got to go and eventually the man who introduced it will also go.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —What a pedestrian performance we have just witnessed. It is more out of decency than from a sense of responsibility that I rise to reply. Where do honourable members opposite stand? On the one hand, the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) criticises the publications put together by the Australian Taxation Office, the video and the 176 pages of explanatory memorandum, and on the other he says that he wants things explained and understood. The Opposition has no clear view at all about this whole area. Let us not talk about confusion the confusion about taxation is on the other side of the House. At Question Time I went through the appalling record of the coalition in respect of tax policy. For years in government the former Treasurer allowed the tax system to resemble a piece of Gruyere cheese with holes in it through which all manner of tax avoidance was driven. We had the former Treasurer representing the slick end of the Liberal Party constituency, where the paper schemes were being put together to rip off the tax system. We had a studied, contrived avoidance by him of the issues for three years solid, until the McCabe-Lafranchi and Costigan reports dragged him screaming to Part IVa. That is the record of the coalition on tax policy.

SPEECH.PARA: The total confusion in taxation is not in what may be termed the unintended consequences of the Government's legislation but in wrestling with the principles of the Opposition as to how this area would be dealt with at all. Let me go through the quotations so that everyone understands where the coalition stands. On the Willesee program last week the Leader of the Opposition was asked by Mr Willesee:
You're not throwing it out completely then?
The Leader of the Opposition replied:
I'm throwing their tax out completely . . .
In other words, he will have a tax himself, but he will not have the Labor Party's tax. He then went on to say:
I will apply a similar approach in government and I will not tolerate arrangements that involve tax avoidance.

In other words, he will attack the problem of non-cash fringe benefits, but he will not attack it in the way the Labor Party has. He said that he would throw our tax out, but he would not tolerate any arrangements that involved tax avoidance. On 24 September on the Carleton-Walsh Report he said:
They will be effectively legislated against.
Richard Carleton asked him how this would be done. He replied:
Well, there are a variety of ways.
Then we have the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair) saying:
There is already an application of some fringe benefits tax by the Tax Commissioner under 26 (e). That is the system that has continued and we have not recommended any change to that.
Then the Deputy Leader of the National Party, the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt), said:

Mr Howard has made it clear that he is not going to allow the fringe benefit issue as such to be a great tax avoidance device. In other words, he is not going to allow company executives to have half their salary paid by kind without tax such as providing a house, interest free loans, a Mercedes Benz car and free education for their children.

The honourable member for Gwydir said that this was obviously a tax avoidance scheme. Then we had the proponent of this proposition, the honourable member for Mackellar saying on the Mike Carlton Show on 2GB:
We just believe that by tackling the biggest abuses in a sensible way, and maybe that's five percent, ten percent of the total . . .
He indicated that they could do something about that. He went on:

What I've said is, that under the original law, there was a capacity, administratively, if people had wanted to work it out properly in a properly controlled management situation to crack down on the rorts and you had to do that.
He continued:
. . . I think that's a fairly simple management problem to solve.

In other words, as far as he is concerned, all this can be tackled in a sensible management way under the existing provisions. In the House of Representatives on 8 May 1986, the honourable member for Mackellar said:

We in the Opposition have a very clear view that rorts should not be allowed in this area; that, if rorts are there, they should be cleaned up; that the principle of taxation must be maintained; that benefits are taxable in the hands of the person getting the benefit; and that if they are not fair they should be cleaned up.

That is where the Opposition stands, if one can find where it stands. Opposition members are all over the place. They know that they cannot defend these non-cash benefits, but they do not have any consensus about how these problems should be tackled. The Taxation Commissioner made a speech today about section 26 (e) in which he said:
I do however have a power of recall and observe that anyone who would say that all that is needed is a return to application of the old law is either ignoring history-
and here is a nice little barb against his former Treasurer-
or has a poor memory, not to speak of a lack of appreciation of the technical inadequacies in that law.
No one seems to question that cash remuneration of an employee is properly subject to income tax. It is very hard to think of a circumstance where the central principle is not followed through.

That does seem to me to be an appropriate general point of reference, a benchmark, when one is considering fringe benefits, i.e., effective supplements to the cash remuneration of employees. And it is appropriate for me as an administrator to observe that, at the level of administrative calls on an employer, a fringe benefits tax formally levied on the employer stands in fair company with pay-as-you-earn concepts.
He went on:

It is well accepted that, each pay-day, the employer should calculate and make tax deductions that, in the aggregate, will closely approximate to the tax on each employee's remuneration of that year . . . I do not need a long memory to recall that we were being criticised a while ago for being too quick off the mark in publishing our initial, but quite extensive, booklet on the tax.

The most damning thing in that speech-I might mention that the Commissioner gave me a copy as a courtesy-is that he is saying that section 26(e) is not capable of being used to deal with non-cash fringe benefits. He made that quite clear to the former Treasurer. In 1977 Malcolm Fraser wrote to Sir Phillip Lynch and said:
My dear Treasurer,

I would like to draw to your attention a paper which Dale Budd passed to Andrew Hay a couple of days ago. The paper, which was prepared by a person outside the government, sets out a number of tax avoidance schemes which are said to be in current use.
I believe that the documents should be examined most urgently and that if the schemes are correctly described we should be looking to appropriate legislation at the earliest possible date.
The paper is also being examined by my own Department.
Yours sincerely,
Malcolm Fraser.

That letter was signed on 15 July 1977. Most of those tax avoidance schemes were straw companies, which were not touched until 1980, when the former Treasurer did his skilful dance around the land mines of this area so as not to touch them. Interestingly, Sir Phillip Lynch said in his reply:
I am also enclosing a copy of a general paper on the question of avoidance of tax which I had earlier asked the Commissioner to prepare for me.
What was one of the areas involved? Fringe benefits. Sir Phillip went on:

This is an area of the law which concerns large numbers of employees who receive part of their remuneration by way of fringe benefits. The present provisions of the income tax law, section 26(e), exposed these benefits to tax. They are not, however, satisfactory-
that is, the present provisions are not satisfactory-
because the benefits are neither quantified nor identified. Proposals to deal specifically with some at least of these benefits are to be developed for consideration during the autumn sittings . . .

That is the autumn sittings of Parliament in 1978. That was when the Opposition was told about fringe benefits. In 1977 it was told that section 26 (e) could not be used because it neither quantified nor identified the benefits. In other words, the Opposition turned its back on the whole issue of payment of non-cash benefits as far back as 1977. The Tax Commissioner, who was the Second Commissioner in those days, is now saying today that section 26 (e) cannot be used because the law is deficient. That is why the Government has introduced a positive tax called the fringe benefits tax. At least Malcolm Fraser had the decency to write to his Treasurer and tell him to do something about these things. Of course, that letter was written in July 1977, and in December 1978 he had the honourable member for Bennelong as Treasurer, who was not going to upset the Liberal Party by knocking out any of these rorts. Oh, no! He intended to leave them there. He did not intend to touch the straw company schemes, the bottom of the harbour schemes, because he had his career in the Liberal Party to protect. As a result, fringe benefits went the way of the paper schemes, the criminal schemes.

This Government has come along and pointed out that it cannot tell the ordinary wage earners on $15,000 or $16,000 a year to pay their way with PAYE taxation and at the same time support a couple of kids, while other people are getting massive benefits outside the taxation system-non-cash benefits which are not taxable. This Government has come along and taxed those benefits. Our Bill reflects all the complexities of the arrangements built up during the years of neglect. The Bill must reflect the complexity of the arrangements put there in the years of the previous Administration. Of course the Bill is complex because arrangements with which it must deal and which it mirrors are also complex. Opposition members think there is some virtue in their position. They say that because the arrangements are complex they should not be there. They claim they will throw out our tax lock, stock and barrel. In other words, they will return to the situation which prevailed in 1977 when Malcolm Fraser wrote that letter to Sir Phillip Lynch. Where is the virtue or morality in that position? If there is an unintended consequence of what is very much a widespread application of the law in this area, why does the Opposition think that any repair of those positions reflects virtue on its position? It reflects none. The Opposition has no moral basis on taxation. It proved that when it was in government and it let criminal schemes proliferate. At Question Time I went through letter after letter. A letter from the Commissioner of Taxation in June 1978 mentioned 30 cases of straw company evasions reported from Adelaide. The Commissioner of Taxation went on to say:

It appears that at least 326 Victorian companies were acquired by a company controlled by a particular promoter, which then stripped them of their assets with the result that the companies have been left without resources to pay large amounts of tax legally due.

That is the sort of stuff which the Opposition tolerated. This Government has come along and said: `Let's try to make the system more decent, let's change it, let's get some basis of fairness in the system. Don't leave the poor old slave who is working his guts out for low levels of remuneration to pay all his tax on a PAYE basis to fund some other people who are not and to let them off'. The Opposition sees some short term advantage in attacking this. We reject the Opposition's views absolutely.

I would not mind if the Opposition said that it will come clean and will tax this in a particular way, but it will not even say where it will do it, although it says that it will do it and keeps making references to section 26 (e). The Opposition knows damn well that a succession of Commissioners of Taxation have said that section 26 (e) is incapable of being used. If the Opposition wants to tax non-cash fringe benefits, there is no resort but to a fringe benefits tax. If the Opposition does not like this one, it will have to have another one, but it will be much the same. Even if the Opposition were to put the tax on the employee, it would have to assess, compute and withhold it. The Opposition does not understand these things, because basically it wants to see the system rorted again.

I know where the Opposition stands-it basically supports the people out there. If members of the Opposition had their time in government over again and the criminal paper schemes were on the go again, they would let them go because that is the sort of people they are. The Opposition has supported the spivs in the system and always will. It has always supported the cheap money out there and always will. Let me tell the Opposition this: In the face of this pedestrian performance by Old Rosy a couple of minutes ago, there is not a chance of the Government being in the slightest way impressed by any case the Opposition may wish to make.

The fact of the matter is that this Government will reduce marginal rates of tax as no other government has. It will introduce a full imputation system for business. Under the Liberal Party Government the effective tax rate on small business was 80 per cent, with the double taxation of dividends. Under this Labor Party Government it will be reduced to 41 per cent and, along with that tax change, there will be a sensible tax on non-cash fringe benefits. No mealy-mouthed charge by the Opposition will divert us from that course. We will have this review of the unintended consequences of the dragnet administration reflecting the complexities of all these arrangements and when we do that the taxation system will continue to be repaired as in any sensible, modern democracy it should be. We will be rejecting the opportunist claptrap coming from the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Treasurer's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the Treasurer (Mr Keating) back to Australia and I am happy to have the opportunity to do so. There is no doubt-let us give credit where credit is due-the Treasurer had a better trip than he did last time. Do honourable members remember that? Wherever he went the people gave him nought out of 10 for economic management and every time he left a capital city the Australian dollar took a dive. He has done a bit better this time. We on this side of the House have been thinking of him as he has darted in and out of the antique shops of London and New York. I have no doubt that he has been absolutely spitting chips as he has heard the news coming from Australia in the past week or so.

SPEECH.PARA: The point which the Treasurer fails to understand is that Australians are sick and tired of having a government which keeps upping the tax hike. People have had enough of tax, which is why the Opposition will get rid of this fringe benefits tax lock, stock and barrel. There is no question about it at all. When it comes to ripping into ordinary Australian taxpayers, there is no doubt that the Treasurer enjoys his work. This is the man who prides himself on being a tax reformer. Remember that wonderful quote in June 1985 when he said:
We're not shrinking violets and we're not about to disappear when the first whiff of grapeshot passes the trenches.

Well, Government members have been disappearing pretty quickly since that statement was made. Senator Grimes is about to go and all the minders in the office of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) had a feeling for what was happening and most of them have departed. More recently, when the Treasurer was under attack from his own side, from various Labor Premiers, he displayed considerable arrogance-I might say that we are used to it-when, on 8 August 1986, he said:
We didn't fight for this thing to see it squandered by some pressure group getting in touch with a Labor Leader's office. I mean we are not going to change this thing . . .
Famous last words. Then, on 12 August, he went one better. He must choke on this as he hears it again. He was quoted in the Melbourne Sun as saying:
There's not going to be any administrative changes-that's it.

That is it, all right! After last week's debacle, I read some Press reports on the weekend to the effect that once the Treasurer was back everything would be all right in Australia, the economy would be all right; that the Treasurer would be back in full control and he would walk into Question Time and throw his weight around as usual-call the Opposition sleazebags and whatever-and she'll be jake. Right on cue, he was there today at Question Time and again in his speech just a moment ago talking about headless chooks, puny questions and criminal schemes with which certain people are supposed to be associated. If ever there were a case of the fox being placed in charge of the chicken yard or the fowl yard, this is it. How ridiculous is it?

This Treasurer is the biggest taxing Treasurer Australia has ever had. While the confusion is everywhere, we should not forget the underlying figures. I released today some figures prepared by the statistics group of the Parliamentary Library. We should not forget that the fringe benefits tax has been brought in on the basis that it will bring equity and fairness back into the system and will do something for the pay as you earn taxpayer. So, in a sense it is part of a package to fund some tax cuts. Let us get the figures straight on this. The effective net tax of an ordinary Australian family, where the husband works for average weekly earnings and the wife manages the home and two children, when the Liberals left office in March 1983 was $52.12 per week. After the so-called tax cuts in July 1987 the tax will be $94.50; a massive increase of $42.38 per week.

Today's debate is on the confusion, frustration and high cost burden on the community arising from the Government's muddled decision making and appalling administration of the fringe benefits tax-a very apt title for the debate. The Treasurer has been away, so perhaps that explains why he has not been reading the news- papers. In regard to this debate, who better to turn to see whether or not it is a fair statement than the Labor Party Government's back bench. On the front page of the Melbourne Herald last Friday was the headline `Labor MP's list 20 fringe tax blunders'. They were being generous; they have hardly scratched the surface. The honourable member for McMillan (Mr Cunningham) has a third option of how to deal with the fringe benefits tax. Quite frankly, Government members do not know whether they are Arthur or Martha.

Let us look at some of these examples-parking spaces provided by employers and taxi fares given to employees who leave work after hours. Why should it be a rort for an employer to pay a taxi fare for a staff member to get home in safety? Why is that a rort and why will the Treasurer not come in here and explain to the Australian people the reality of this tax increase? In my electorate are the towns of Newhaven and San Remo, which have good fishing fleets. There is a fringe benefits tax on the provision of accommodation for fishermen catching shark and whatever in Bass Strait. How ridiculous! Yet the Treasurer has the cheek to come into the House and say that the whole thing is just a sideshow.

Let me say something about the log book. If anybody listening to the debate today finds the log book confusing, I offer only one consolation-the Treasurer himself does not have a clue how it works. I must say that it is a very frustrating thing to have to fill out. I have a log book for substantiation reasons. It is no sideshow for the Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, which has to pay a fringe benefits tax on homes for lost animals. TALK.START.PARA: —If honourable members listened to the contributions of the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) and the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) in this debate, they would know that there is a missing dimension. If the Opposition is to do that, the first question is: How will it prevent a continuation of the massive erosion of the income tax base by the use of fringe benefits in lieu of cash income and all the inequity that flows from that, which is well documented? There is no doubt that, in the period leading up to the introduction of this tax, we have seen an increasing proportion of executive salaries, particularly at the high end, comprising non-cash fringe benefits. So we would see a continuation and, I suggest, an exacerbation of that basic inequity. The other thing that the Opposition will need to address is what it will do about the revenue forgone as a result; and we are talking about substantial amounts of revenue. According to the explanatory notes to the original legislation we are looking at $330m for 1986-87, $540m for 1987-88 and $625m for 1988-89. Those are significant sums of money which will be forgone if the Opposition abandons the aim of effectively taxing fringe benefits.

Earlier this afternoon we again heard the Leader of the National Party talking in the debate on the statement made by the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley). He set out a long agenda of things that the Opposition would seek in the defence area, if it got back into government, all of which involved the expenditure of significant sums of money. Yet there seems to be no concern within the Opposition about reconciling that goal of increasing expenditures in certain areas and rejecting a number of other government tax revenue measures, on the one hand, with its stated goal of reducing the magnitude of public sector borrowings and the Budget deficit, on the other. There seems to be absolutely no concern whatsoever with getting a position which is consistent over time, in terms of the statements made by different Opposition spokesmen at different times, or internally consistent or coherent at any given time, coming up with a position which is a mathematical absurdity in terms of what it says it will do about the revenue side and the expenditure side, on the one hand, and what it will do about the Budget deficit and the public sector borrowing requirement, on the other. It is an absolute absurdity.

Basically, if the Opposition forgoes the revenue from the fringe benefits tax there are three possibilities. The first is to have marginal tax rates higher than they might otherwise be-an additional burden on honest taxpayers. The second is to have a Budget deficit larger than it might otherwise have been. Of course, if we are to take seriously this statement about the need to wind back the public sector borrowing requirement, we see that there is obviously an inconsistency there. The other possibility is to go for further expenditure cuts. Of course, the Opposition consistently calls for further expenditure cuts, but it consistently fails to describe where those cuts will be made. The fact of the matter is that it cannot identify areas where cuts could be made in a reasonable and equitable way, so it simply opts out of that argument by saying that it will announce that at some appropriate time. So the first option that the Opposition might pursue, if it chooses to go down the path of not taxing fringe benefits in any effective or substantive way, shows its utter bankruptcy and its lack of any integrity whatsoever.

The second possibility is for the Opposition to try to tax fringe benefits in some way other than what the Government is proposing to do. The method that it has described is to seek to enforce the existing section 26(e) of the Income Tax Assessment Act. As the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has pointed out, a number of Commissioners of Taxation, including Commissioners of Taxation under the former coalition Government, have made it clear that section 26(e) is inappropriate. In fact, the tax White Paper sets out a number of reasons why section 26(e) is inappropriate. I do not think any reputable tax authority would argue that it is an administratively feasible or practicable method of collecting tax on fringe benefits. The Opposition keeps referring to it in a totally intellectually dishonest manner because it knows full well that it simply will not work.

If we did seek to go down that path of collecting fringe benefits tax through the existing section 26 (e), what would be the consequences? As well as the administrative burden imposed on employers by the existing tax, there would be a comparable, if not larger, burden on employers because they would have to apportion individually the value of fringe benefits going to individual employees. Furthermore, individual taxpayers would have to include in their returns the benefit and a valuation. Therefore it would be an additional burden on the individual taxpayer as well as the employers. It is an utterly laughable and untenable position and one that honourable members opposite really cannot defend. No other suggestion has come from the Opposition, except some gunk from the Opposition spokesperson on Treasury matters about administrative measures, whatever that is supposed to mean, with no elaboration or clarification whatsoever of what he has in mind. It is absolutely clear that the Opposition's position on fringe benefits is a joke. I do not think it ought to be taken seriously at all.

There is no doubt that with a set of tax measures of the magnitude and significance of the fringe benefits tax, which aims to address a plethora, a multiplicity, of different methods of providing benefits in the form of non-cash fringe benefits, we will have a necessarily complex piece of legislation. Necessarily there will be teething problems and necessarily in the early stages there will be unintended consequences. A proper attempt is required to be carried out in good faith to remove those anomalies, to minimise the administrative burden associated with the tax to the bare minimum that is possible and, at the same time, to avoid throwing out the baby with the bath water and bringing in exemptions, rules or simplifications such as to defy the overall purpose of the tax measure and to reduce dramatically the revenue collected.

That is not an easy task. The Government has set about doing it in good faith. I am hopeful that in due course these problems will be minimised and that we will see, as with the prescribed payments system, for example, after some initial teething problems, that the tax will come to be an accepted and reasonable effective revenue raising measure.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON ENVIRONMENT AND CONSERVATION

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation, I present the report of the Committee on Namadgi National Park, together with the transcripts of evidence and extracts of the minutes of proceedings.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The interest of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation in the administrative arrangements for Namadgi National Park in the Australian Capital Territory goes back some time, to at least 1981 when the Committee in the Thirty-second Parliament referred to the park in a report that dealt with the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act. Our recent inquiry, on which we are reporting today, was prompted by concerns that self-government for the Australian Capital Territory could result in a reduction of the resources available for the management of the park or might lead to parts of the park being transferred to other land uses. Our inquiries revealed a number of matters that required attention regardless of whether the Australian Capital Territory becomes self-governing, and these have been dealt with in our report.

SPEECH.PARA: I understand that there is considerable interest within bureaucratic circles in this report and there has been some speculation about whether we will recommend that responsibility for the administration and management of Namadgi be transferred from one authority to another. It appears that the two authorities which could conceivably manage Namadgi-that is, the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service or the Parks and Conservation Service of the Department of Territories-have not enjoyed the best of relationships over the years. I am not surprised therefore that there is some consternation that we might recommend a change in the administrative arrangements. We found that one of the most disturbing things about Namadgi was this lack of co-operation between the two organisations. Both have separately developed good working relationships with State national parks and wildlife services but seem unable to get along with one another to the full extent that would be desirable. We found that if the poor relationship between the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service and the Department of Territories could be improved the management of Namadgi might benefit. We have made a number of recommendations aimed at improving this relationship and creating better co-operation and liaison between the two agencies.

The main issue considered by the inquiry was the security of tenure of the park. The tenure question is linked to the question of who should manage the park because security of tenure could be provided under the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act and if the Act were used for this purpose it could have the effect of transferring authority for managing the park from the Department of Territories to the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service. National parks and equivalent reserves in most of the States have a much more secure tenure than is the case with Namadgi. An Act of parliament or a similar measure is required to degazette parks once they are declared in the States. The Commonwealth National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act also provides that once a park is declared it can be revoked only by a proclamation by the Governor-General acting in accordance with a resolution passed by both Houses of this Parliament. By comparison, we were advised that parts of Namadgi or even the whole park could be degazetted and made available for some other purpose simply by the Minister placing a notice in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette.

We found that Namadgi had significant values at the local, regional and national levels and therefore consider that the existing tenure arrangements are totally inadequate. Perhaps for the benefit of honourable members I should explain that Namadgi includes the magnificent mountain range which forms such an impressive backdrop to Canberra. Indeed, Namadgi includes most of the southern and western parts of the Australian Capital Territory and the most important Cotter Valley which provides most of Canberra's water supply. The park has been described by the Department of Territories as being of outstanding value for nature conservation and as a scientific reference area. Clearly, a national park that can be described in these terms deserves a stronger security of tenure than presently provided.

We considered various options to provide this tenure and concluded that the protection which would be offered if the area were declared under the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act was the best that could possibly be afforded. Consequently, we have recommended that Nam- adgi National Park be declared a national park under the Act but-I stress this qualification-that this declaration should not proceed until the Department of Territories and the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service agree to the Director of the Service delegating all his responsibilities and powers under the Act as they apply to Namadgi to the Department of Territories. Let me make it quite clear that, although we consider that it is necessary for the park to be declared under the Act, we do not propose that any aspect of the planning, administration and development of Namadgi should be transferred from the Department of Territories to the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service. This is why we consider that declaration under the Act should occur only when there is agreement about the delegation of powers between the two organisations involved. We define a role for the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service which would allow the Service to provide assistance in a way which would not interfere with the Department's day to day management of the park. This could be similar to the Service's involvement with State park services through assistance and co-ordination programs.

Other matters which concern the Committee and on which we have reported included the separation of planning and management functions between the National Capital Development Commission and the Department of Territories, the apparent lack of departmental awareness of Aboriginal interest in the park and the need to amend the Australian Capital Territory Nature Conservation Ordinance. To this end we have made recommendations aimed at providing the Department of Territories with full responsibility for planning and development, ensuring that the Department examines the extent of Aboriginal interest and possible involvement and that high priority is given to amending the Ordinance. Before concluding, I would like to place on record the Committee's appreciation of the assistance and information provided by officers of the Department of Territories and also my thanks, once again, for the efforts of the Committee's secretariat, particularly Mr Ian Dundas, who was secretary to the inquiry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fisher Mr P.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-This report adequately expresses the views of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation on the natural and cultural value of Namadgi, which encompasses 40 per cent of the Australian Capital Territory. As a committee we do not overstate its significance as a national park, but as part of the alpine region it does have a diversity of plants, animals, scenic beauty, and some elements of cultural significance that should be preserved. It is, indeed, a beautiful part of Australia. However, the role of this region in land management and planning for Canberra's water catchment and as open space should be emphasised. The report, therefore, deals with these aspects in detail. Despite this, Namadgi is not just of local importance. The deliberations of our Committee recommend declaration as a national park under the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975, but with the Department of Territories retaining all responsibilities, powers of management and control as delegated from the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service. We believe this recommendation will overcome the inadequate legislation arrangements that presently exist, ensure that revocation cannot occur, and that there will be a requirement for preparation and adoption of management plans. Many of these aspects have already been fully discussed by the Chairman and will be further broadened by the Deputy Chairman when he speaks in this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek to expand on a number of further points. Firstly, it has been obvious that the Australian Capital Territory Parks and Conservation Service is a professional, dedicated organisation and is restrained only by its budget. Our recommendations will enhance its competence through greater integration and the opportunity for participation, such as voluntary exchanges between the various conservation services, and consulting with the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service. The second point I raise is the apparent variance of views expressed by both the Department of Territories and the National Capital Development Commission over a period. This can be interpreted only as self-interest in retaining respective power bases and has resulted in a lack of co-operation between authorities as well as delays. This situation simply cannot be condoned. The conduct of this inquiry brought forward responses and actions that should have been forthcoming many years earlier if the Namadgi had been treated with the respect it deserves and assistance had been sought from the appropriate sources. The Government should accept and implement these recommendations so that Namadgi will have security of tenure and so that revocation of its status will require an Act of parliament and not be at the whim of a Minister or any future municipal or territory government.

Finally, I must comment on some of the double standards that have surfaced during this inquiry. It is absolutely legitimate and important for concerned people, whether they be landholders, political parties or park users, to indicate their views in a robust manner. But I find it of great concern that individuals in the political life of the Australian Capital Territory, at both the parliamentary and political party level and within departments, who were noticeably silent when this Committee was involved in the important issues of national significance such as the development and creation of the Great Barrier Reef National Park, Uluru National Park, Kakadu National Park or the South West Tasmanian issue, should suddenly be both vocal and of conflicting opinion on the Namadgi question.

This report is not just a management document. It provides an approach for the protection and development of an important region of Australia, but takes into account its local and regional significance to the national capital and to its people. I commend this report to the House and also join with the Chairman in thanking Mr Ian Dundas and the secretariat of the Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation for their support and competence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Webster Mr A.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The management and development of the Namadgi National Park is a significant case study in the alignment of national and local conservation, recreation and development priorities, involving as it does the overlapping interests of the nation, the States and a local community, and overlapping responsibilities and plans held by different Commonwealth departments and authorities. This report recommends, I believe, a very satisfactory resolution of the overlapping and potentially conflicting interests and responsibilities.

SPEECH.PARA: The House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation has approached the question of the park by considering ways in which it can be protected and developed as a permanent reserve and how it can be managed to best take account of its local, regional and national values. It has sought to maximise local involvement and control while ensuring that in future lower priority is not given to the national importance and conservation values.

The Committee acknowledges a number of key factors involved in determining the weight to be given to the park's national significance against its importance to local development needs. The park represents 40 per cent of the total area of the Australian Capital Territory and provides not just the scenic background to the city but the city's main water catchment and the greatest threat to the Territory's citizens in terms of bush- fires. The Cotter catchment is identified as being of such high value for nature conservation research and reference that the Department of Territories proposes to manage the area as a special scientific area. The Australian Heritage Commission considers that the Namadgi region contains a rare collection of prehistoric and historic sites which have remained comparatively intact so that the extent, variety and integrity of the area's cultural record are probably unique in Australia. Finally, the park is an important gateway to the entire Australian Alps, which it can be argued are of international significance.

In the face of these factors, the Committee was obviously obliged to recommend what it considers the most efficient and effective arrangements for future park planning and management. Let me just outline what the Committee concluded in this regard. Firstly, the Department of Territories management of the park is generally very good and its Parks and Conservation Service is a competent and professional organisation. Secondly, there is no aspect of the Department's day to day administration of the park which suggests that there is need to transfer responsibility to the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service. Thirdly, it would be inefficient to create a separate organisation to deal with Namadgi while the rest of the Territory was managed by the existing organisations within the Department. Fourthly, there has been and is a poor level of co-operation between the Department and the National Parks and Wildlife Service and the failure to co-operate has certainly contributed to unnecessary delays in planning and developing Namadgi and has possibly resulted in avoidable extra cost. Fifthly, the Service should be able to assist the Department in the same way as it assists the States. Sixthly, the Department's record on spending on Namadgi compares favourably with those of other authorities on other parks; that staffing in this area has been adequate; and that the transfer of the park to the Service would not see an increase in general provision of resources. Finally, the Service could provide program, research, and training assistance in a way which would not interfere with the Department's day to day management role.

The Committee also dealt with the question of the adequacy of legislation covering the park. We believe that the park should receive the highest level of protection against casual degazettal similar to that afforded to other national parks. The Committee concluded that an Act was preferable to an ordinance and accepted that as adequate provisions exist within the existing National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act, no new legislation was needed. The Committee believes that security of tenure would be provided for the park if it was a national park under that Act. We have sought to ensure that there are no difficulties or interference for local administration and that priorities in areas such as water supply and bushfire management occur. Let me emphasise that, as a member representing the Blue Mountains area of New South Wales, I share the concerns of local Territorians about control of these matters. It would be intolerable if local control were lost over the water supply and bushfire prevention activities in particular.

Our recommendation in this regard is for a formal agreement for the Director of the National Parks and Wildlife Service to delegate his powers and the Service's functions to the Department of Territories under the provisions of the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act. Such a delegation could be guaranteed by specifying the Department's role in the management plan which comes before the Parliament and by formal memoranda of understanding and agreements between the relevant Ministers and departments.

I want to refer to only one other area of recommendations by the Committee. The Committee considered that it is timely to review the need for a broadly based consultative and advisory group to provide public input on general conservation matters in the Territory. This matter of consultation and local government involvement in decision making is particularly urgent in regard to aboriginal groups. The Committee considers THAT the Department has not consulted Aboriginal groups or considered sufficiently their interests in Namadgi. This management plan does not make any provision for such consultation. There is an urgent need to involve Aboriginals in consultation on the park's future management and to determine the extent of interest and claims by various Aboriginal groups.

I wish to conclude by expressing, as others have done, my appreciation for the various submissions the Committee received and noting the quality of the submissions and the intensity of local concern for this beautiful park. I must also note the excellent work of the Department's Parks and Conservation Service in its past stewardship of this natural resource. I have every confidence that this report provides a workable formula for the joint oversight of what is without doubt a major national and local resource. I commend the report to my colleagues and look forward to reviewing its successful implementation a year or so from now. I echo the compliments paid to Mr Ian Dundas and other members of the secretariat who assisted us in the preparation of this report.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services)

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scott Mr J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 11 February 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does article XII of the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) Statute, as amended to June 1973, require the IAEA to carry out inspections on specialised equipment and facilities, including nuclear reactors to ensure that they (a) will not further any military purpose, (b) comply with applicable health and safety standards and (c) will provide effective safeguards as laid down in the statute.
(2) Is he able to say how many inspectors have been employed by the IAEA in each year since June 1973.

(3) Is he also able to say (a) what the qualifications are of the inspectors, (b) what general qualifications are required by the IAEA for inspectors, (c) from what countries the inspectors are recruited by the IAEA, (d) how many inspections have been carried out by the IAEA since its formation, (e) in what countries the inspections were carried out, (f) at what locations the inspections were carried out, (g) what type of equipment was inspected, (h) whether any of the inspections were carried out at military installations and (j) whether any of the equipment was (i) of a military nature or (ii) fulfilling a military purpose.
(4) Are the findings and subsequent reports of these inspections available to the signatory member countries of the IAEA.
(5) If the findings are available will he supply the details of all the inspections and subsequent findings and report to the Parliament; if not, why not.
(6) What amounts have been paid by Australian Governments to the IAEA in each year since the Statute Approval Conference on 23 October 1956.

(7) What percentage of its annual budget does the IAEA spend on inspection staff by way of salaries, wages, travel and other related expenses and all other expenses incurred by inspectors during the course of employment with the IAEA.

(8) Is he able to say whether inspections have been or will be carried out at the Kerr McGee nuclear fuel plant in Oklahoma, USA, where, according to reports in The Australian and The Advertiser of 6 January 1986, an accident occurred in which a worker was killed and a number of other workers were injured.
(9) Will he secure the fullest possible information on all aspects of this accident and furnish the Parliament with the details of any Australian uranium involved.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Article XII of the Statute of the International Atomic Energy Agency is a constitutional provision, entitled ``Agency Safeguards'', which records in paragraph A the agreement of Parties to the Statute that if there should be an ``Agency project'' or ``other arrangement where the Agency is requested by the party concerned to apply safeguards'' then the Agency shall be entitled to exercise certain rights and responsibilities to the extent relevant to the ``project or arrangement''. Paragraph A of the Article is in effect a charter of possibilities rather than a binding directive to the Agency; in practice, the extent to which rights and responsibilities are exercised depends on agreements negotiated between the Agency and the State or States concerned and concluded between them after approval by the Board of Governors of the Agency.
Among the rights and responsibilities which the Agency may thus agree to exercise is, according to sub-paragraph A.1 of the Article:

``To examine the design of specialized equipment and facilities, including nuclear reactors, and to approve it only from the view-point of assuring that it will not further any military purpose, that it complies with applicable health and safety standards, and that it will permit effective application of the safeguards provided for in this article;''

Agency projects for the purposes of Article XII, are those for which individual bilateral agreements between the Agency and the Member State are approved by the Board of Governors. The agreements might cover supply by or through the Agency of materials, services, equipment and facilities to the Member State. Not all Agency projects involve significant non-proliferation or health and safety risks; they might not involve, for example, source or special fissionable material, in which case safeguards inspections would not be required to be provided for in the relevant agreement. In short, Article XII in its application to Agency projects does not require the Agency to carry out inspections, whether of specialised equipment, facilities including nuclear reactors, nuclear material or other material, but is the Agency's constitutional authority for agreeing to do so in appropriate cases.
There is only a small number of ``Agency projects'' within the meaning of that term in Article XII.

The great bulk of safeguards activities carried out by the Agency are done in relation to ``other arrangement(s) whereby the Agency is requested by the party concerned to apply safeguards'', as envisaged by Article XII.A of the Statute. There is such an arrangement between the Agency and the States which are parties to the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons (NPT); for this Treaty the Board of Governors approved a safeguards approach, the provisions of which are spelled out in detail in Agency document INFCIRC/153, which the Agency applies for the purposes of the NPT under individual safeguards agreements which the non-nuclear-weapon States are required under the Treaty to conclude with the IAEA. The rights and responsibilities of the Agency in applying such safeguards flow directly from the individual agreements and not from Article XII as such.

Similarly the Agency's rights and responsibilities for safeguards activities in nuclear-weapon States, and in States which are not party to the NPT, flow from individual safeguards agreements between the Agency and the respective States rather than directly from Article XII of the Statute. For nuclear-weapon States, the safeguards approach in the agreements is similar to that used in agreements required in connection with the NPT for non-nuclear-weapon States. For other States the approach is that in the Agency's safeguards system based on the Agency document, approved by the Board of Governors, known as INFCIRC/66/Rev.2.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: United Nations: Allegations by United States Senator D. P. Moynihan

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Klugman Dr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 21 August 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to allegations by Senator D. P. Moynihan on pages 9 and 10 of the ``New Leader'' of 5-19 May 1986.
(2) Is it a fact that the USSR violates article 100 of the UN Charter.
(3) Is he able to say whether a lieutenant colonel in the KGB is head of UN personnel in Geneva and controls recruitment.
(4) Was Hermann Klenner from the German Democratic Republic appointed to head the UN Human Rights Commission in Geneva.
(5) Is he able to say whether Herr Klenner is a former member of the Nazi Party.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) Article 100 (1) of the Charter of the UN provides that in the performance of their duties the Secretary-General and the staff shall not seek or receive instructions from any government or from any other authority external to the organisation. They shall refrain from any action which might reflect on their position as international officials responsible only to the organisation.

Article 100 (2) requires that each member of the United Nations respect the exclusively international character of the responsibilities of the Secretary-General and the staff and not to seek to influence them in the discharge of their responsibilities.
There are grounds for believing that nationals of the Soviet Union in the Secretariat of the United Nations are subject to direction from their government.

For example, it is generally understood that all Soviet members of the Secretariat are required to pay a proportion of their salary to their government. This is of concern to the Australian Government because such a practice reflects on the position of Soviet employees as international officials.

(3) The current head of UN Personnel in Geneva is Mr Villanueva, a Spanish national. His predecessor was Mr Dneprovsky, a Soviet national. Reports concerning Mr Dneprovsky, such as those in the article referred to, date back to 1978 and were the subject of a question without notice in the Senate on 23 May 1979. The situation remains that the Government is not in a position to confirm the accuracy of the reports, in accordance with the Government's long-established policy of not commenting on intelligence and security matters.

(4) & (5) I understand the German Democratic Republic has withdrawn the candidature of Dr Klenner for the position of Chairman of the Forty-third Session of the Human Rights Commission in 1987. This action followed allegations in the media in the Federal Republic of Germany that Dr Klenner was a former member of the Nazi Party. I am unaware of any information which would substantiate the charge.

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Department developed a specification for the Department of Housing and Construction in August 1983 to provide security in every Regional Office as Stratplan was implemented. This was endorsed by the Protective Security Committee in 1984.

(3) to (5) To this point the Departmental Security Committee has not recommended any changes to the package.
